fibers can clog pool filters and create the need for expensive repairs. 

16. Children who are not toilet-trained are not allowed in either the main pool or the kiddy pool without a “swim” diaper 
and must always be accompanied by an adult within arm’s length.  Children wearing regular diapers are not allowed in 
either the main pool or the kiddy pool.  “Swim” diapers must always be used.  If your child or anyone else in your party 
is found to be responsible for a closure due to fecal matter, all costs to clean and reopen the pool may be assigned to 
your household via your HOA account.  If a fecal accident occurs: All swimmers must exit the pool immediately and the 
pool will be closed for the minimum time frame as allowed by law from the time the pool has been chemically treated.  
Incidents should be immediately reported to the current HOA management company and/or the Pool Monitor on duty. 

17. Persons having currently active diarrhea or who have had active diarrhea within the previous 14 days are not allowed to 
enter the pool water. 

18. No smoking or any other use of tobacco products (Skoal, chewing tobacco, vapor cigarettes, etc.).  The following are not 
permitted in the pool area or surrounding park under any circumstances: alcohol, firearms, or drugs.  Individuals 
engaging in the use of such are subject to loss of privileges for a period to be determined by the HOA Board. Other legal 
actions may be taken in conjunction with the Williamson County Sheriff’s Office. 

19. Swim safely and treat others as you would like to be treated.  Residents are responsible for the behavior of those in their 
household and/or their guests. 

20. In the event of inclement weather, swimmers are to clear the pool during the storm and for at least thirty (30) minutes 
after lightning and/or thunder has ceased. 

21. Any resident may call the current HOA management company to report unsafe behavior or violations of pool rules they 
witness.

CHANDLER CREEK HOA

July 27, 2023

Erik T. Figueroa

1111 Thorn Creek Place
Round Rock, TX 78664

Property Address: 1111 Thorn Creek Place 
Account#: CCH20846

Notice of Delinquency and Intent to File a Lien

According to our records, you are delinquent in the payment of the Assessments owed to CHANDLER CREEK 
HOA. The total due, as of the date of this letter, is $1,989.63.

Your account is currently 40 days past due. Demand is hereby made for immediate payment in 
full for the amount described in this notice. You have 45 days from the date of this notice to cure 
this delinquency to avoid further collection action.

To avoid having a delinquent assessment lien prepared and filed against your property by an 
attorney, you have the following options during the 45-day cure period: 

1. make payment in full of all amounts set forth in this notice, or
2. set up a payment plan with the Association.

To set up payment arrangements, please contact PS Property Management prior to the end of the 45-
day cure period.  Please be advised that payment plans are subject to the Association’s payment plan 
guidelines regarding duration and eligibility.  If a delinquent assessment lien is prepared and filed by
an attorney, your account will be charged an escalated collection fee of $450.00.  This fee will not
be waived.  In addition, per your Association’s governing documents, your account will continue to be 
charged late interest each month until the total balance due is paid.

Our management company, PS Property Management, makes paying your bill online quick and easy.  
Visit www.psprop.net to submit your online payment. If mailing your payment, please detach the coupon 
at the bottom of the statement and mail it with your check or money order (payable to Chandler Creek 
HOA) to the payment remittance address on the coupon. Any recent payments received may not be 
reflected on this statement.

CHANDLER CREEK HOA POOL RULES 
Rules/Hours are subject to change 

 
HOURS: 

Regular Season: April 1 to October 31: 7am to 9pm  
Off-season: November 1 to March 31: 7am to 7pm 

 
ONLY RESIDENTS THAT HAVE PAID ALL HOMEOWNER ASSOCIATION ASSESSMENTS WILL BE PERMITTED TO USE THE POOL AND 
TENNIS COURT FACILITIES. 
 

Pool Monitors represent the HOA Board of Directors and have authority to make discretionary rulings on behavior not explicitly 
covered by these and other rules. They are not lifeguards and will not act as such.  Complaints about their rulings should be taken to 
the Association management after first complying with the decision(s) made by the Pool Monitors. Pool Monitors are authorized to 
enforce the following rules including the ejection of non-compliant residents and/or guests. 
 

Any individual(s) reported to be/or found to be in violation of any of these following pool rules will be reported to the Chandler 
Creek Homeowners Association and possibly the Williamson County Sheriff’s Office (as applicable).  The nature of the situation will 
be considered and action(s) toward resolution will be at the Board’s discretion. 
 
1. The Chandler Creek swimming pool is a SWIM AT YOUR OUR RISK pool.  No lifeguards will be on duty.  Children under age 16 

must be accompanied by a Chandler Creek resident 18 years of age or older.  This rule will be strictly enforced. 
 

2. Use of any facility and/or equipment in the pool area is at your discretion.  Please use caution. 
 

3. All residents are required to show their pool pass and a valid State of Texas ID if requested by a Pool Monitor.  Failure to comply 
may result in you being asked to leave the pool area. 
 

4. The access gates can only be opened with a pool access card/fob.  Gates are to remain locked at all times.  The Pool Monitors 
have been instructed not to open the gate for anyone without a pool access card/fob.  Anyone without an access card/fob will

to 
use of the greenbelt and open space lots, as well as the Highpointe trail system. 

Definitions 

"Common Area" means any property and facilities that the Association owns or in which it 
otherwise holds rights or obligations.1 

"Development Area" means a part of the Development that is subject to additional restrictions set 
forth in a Development Area Declaration that applies to such property.2 

"Development Area Declaration" means, with respect to any Development Area, a separate 
instrument containing covenants, restrictions, conditions, limitations and/or easements, 
applicable to the property.3 

"Greenbelt/Open Space Lots" are portions of the Property that are designated on a Plat or in an 
instrument as property to be used as a greenbelt, open space, or a drainage easement and not for 
use as a residential lot. Open space areas may also include fenced karst feature areas, greenbelts 
and re-irrigation areas owned by the Association. Use is restricted to permitted uses only (e.g., 
use of trails established by the Association in accordance with applicable rules or trimming the 
twenty foot (20') strip behind an Owner's fence and property line in accordance with the 
Association's Rules). Otherwise, trespassing is prohibited.4 

1 First Amended and Restated Master Declaration (as amended, the "Declaration"), Definitions 
2 Declaration, Definitions. 
3 Declaration, Definitions. 
4 Design Guidelines. 

HIGHPOINTE DESIGN GUIDELINES PAGE4 



23018808 Page 5 of 42 

"Improvement" means every structure and all appurtenances of every type and kind, whether 
temporary or permanent in nature, including, but not limited to, buildings, outbuildings, storage 
sheds, patios, tennis courts, sport courts, recreational facilities, swimming pools, putting greens, 
garages, driveways, parking areas and/or facilities, storage buildings, sidewalks, fences, gates, 
screening walls, retaining walls, stairs, patios, decks, walkways, landscaping, mailboxes, poles,

retroactively so as to require modification or 
removal of work already approved and completed or approved and in progress. It is the 

HIGHPOINTE DESIGN GUIDELINES PAGE3 



23018808 Page 4 of 42 

responsibility of each Owner to ensure that they have the most current edition of the Design 
Guidelines and every amendment thereto. 

Development Restrictions 

Environmental Restrictions. Portions of Highpointe are located in areas with sensitive 
environmental features. Accordingly, there are limitations, including impervious cover 
restrictions, on development activity in the subdivision. The recorded plats for the subdivision 
are accessible at the following link: https://hayscad.com/subdivisionplats/sublisth/. The plats 
contain information about setbacks, greenbelt lots, and use restrictions. The plats should be 
reviewed along with the recorded governing documents for Highpointe. 

Use of Adjacent Lots. As a general rule, property that is adjacent to your lot that you do not own 
may not be used as an extension of your property. 

Maintaining Adjacent Lots. If your rear property line is adjacent to a greenbelt lot owned by the 
Association, in most cases you have the right to weed eat the property to a distance of up to 20 
feet beyond your rear fence and you may remove small brush and dead cedar trees. All debris, 
branches, leaves, and clippings must be removed from the property. 

Architectural Review. With few exceptions, improvements must be approved by the Association 
in writing before work commences. When in doubt, please inquire by contacting the Association. 
It is NOT better to ask for forgiveness then permission where approval is concerned. The 
governing documents, including the Design Guidelines, contain additional rules pertaining to 
use of the greenbelt and open space lots, as well as the Highpointe trail system. 

Definitions 

"Common Area" means any property and facilities that the Association owns or in which it

DESIGN GUIDELINES 

Revised in 2023 

[HP Property Owners Association, Inc.] 

Hays County, Texas 

Cross Reference to (i) First Amended and Restated Master Declaration of Covenants. Conditions and 
Restrictions for Highpointe [Residential). recorded under Volume 2839, Page 623, Official Public Records of 
Hays County, Texas, as amended; (ii) Highpointe Assignment of Declarant's Rights, recorded under Volume 
3564, Page 499, Official Public Records of Hays County, Texas; and (iii) Assignment of Declarant Rights, 
recorded under Instrument No. 16037855, Official Public Records of Hays County, Texas. 

THIS DOCUMENT AMENDS AND RESTATES THE HIGHPOINTE DESIGN GUIDELINES 
RECORDED AS DOCUMENT NO. 201111026548 IN THE OFFICIAL PUBLIC RECORDS OF 
HAYS COUNTY, TEXAS AND ANY AMENDMENTS OR SUPPLEMENTS THERETO. 



23018808 Page 2 of 42 

Introduction 

Background. Highpointe is a master-planned community located in Hays County, Texas. The 
governing body for the subdivision is the HP Property Owners Association, Inc. (the 
11 Association"). The community is subject to the terms and provisions of the First Amended and 
Restated Master Declaration of Covenants, Conditions and Restrictions - Highpointe Residential, 
recorded in the Official Public Records of Hays County, Texas (as amended, the "Declaration"). 
Within the subdivision there are Development Areas, each of which will be subject to a certain 
Development Area Declaration instrument. The recorded instruments contain important rules 
that Owners are bound by. Capitalized terms used herein but not defined are to be given those 
definitions found in the Declaration. 

The Master Architectural Control Committee 

WRITTEN PRE-APPROVAL IS REQUIRED FOR IMPROVEMENTS. Under Article VI of the

documents.content:
without the 
advance written approval of the Master Architectural Control Committee. All tanks must be 
screened so as not to be visible from any other portion of the Development Area. 

Fencing 

Fencing of front yards is not allowed. Solid walls enclosing an entire site are not permitted. All 
Lots shall have fencing of 6 feet in height and no portion of any fencing may exceed 6 feet in 
height. Fences shall be of wood, black coated wrought iron or decorative metal construction 
approved by the Master Architectural Control Committee. The Fence must be located 10 feet 
from the front elevation of the residence and no farther from the front elevation of the residence 
than the midpoint of the residence. In the event of any dispute or disagreement as to the location 
of a fence on a Lot, the decision of the Master Architectural Control Committee, in it sole and 
absolute discretion, will be final. 

• Wood fences facing an existing or proposed street or other right-of-way must have the 
slats facing the street or public right-of-way and must be stained with "Behr #501 Semi­
Transparent Cedar Tone" or such other natural or neutral colors approved by the Master 
Architectural Control Committee All other fencing between residential lots must be 

HIGHPOINTE DESIGN GUIDELINES PAGE27 



23018808 Page 28 of 42 

"good neighbor fencing". Good Neighbor fencing is defined as wood fencing that 
alternates the side the panel faces every eight feet (8'). Neighbors are permitted to vary 
from this requirement; provided, however, that any such deviation from the Good 
Neighbor Fencing requirement must be, in writing, signed by the Owners of both Lots 
impacted by the agreement, and submitted to the Association with a request for approval 
before installation. The agreement must also provide the period of time that the 
arrangement shall remain in place. 

• Fences along the side yard of corner lots shall not be placed closer to the public right-of­
documents.path: /drives/b!nslWL7oJf0GurAFazjx4oOabfa0q4iZMh47wxSLJiqST3qiwOUFDQ6RKwkvmcuX4/root:/Highpointe HOA/Public/Rules & Policies/Highpointe  POA Highpointe - Design Guidelines (2023) OCR Word Searcheable.pdf

documents.content:
door of the house for the purpose of 
identifying people approaching or at any door of the house." 

Front yard fencing is discouraged. However, if an owner wishes to install security fencing in the 
front yard, the fencing must consist of ornamental wrought iron or metal fencing (painted black) 
with the following general specifications: Pickets ¾" square; Rails 1 ½" square; Standard Posts 2 
½" square; Picket Spacing between 3" and 4"; Post Spacing 8' OC; Height between 48" and 60". 
Slats, planks, or other solid material may not be installed on metal fencing. 

Basketball Goals and Sporting Equipment 

Basketball goals, or backboards, or any other similar sporting equipment of either a permanent or 
temporary nature shall not be placed on any Lot or street or where same would be visible from 
an adjoining street or Lot without the prior written consent of the Master Architectural Control 
Committee. 

Permanent goals must meet the following criteria: 
• the metal pole must be permanently mounted into the ground to the side of the driveway 

in a full upright position 25' back from the curb; 
• the pole, backboard and net must be maintained in good condition at all times; and 
• poles may not be installed in front of the garage or facing into the street. 

Portable goals will not be allowed unless the following criteria are met: 
• the goal must be placed to the side of the driveway and permanently installed to be flush 

with the ground and maintained at all times in a full upright position 25' back from the 
curb; 

• the pole, backboard and net must be maintained in good condition at all times; 

HIGHPOINTE DESIGN GUIDELINES PAGE 30 



23018808 Page 31 of 42 

• poles may not be installed in front of the garage or facing the street; 
• landscape barrier, such as small shrubs must screen the base of the goal; 
• goals may not be rolled into the street or any other public right-of-way; and

2. Use of Adjacent Lots. As a general rule, property that is adjacent to your lot that you do not

documents.content:
by local building codes and have all applicable building 
permits in place before construction begins. 

• All materials used match those of the home, including siding, brick, windows, and paint 
color, shingles, etc. 

• The improvement must be compatible with the architectural elements of the existing 
house. Paint colors and materials must match those of the house. 

• The design should reflect consideration for any adverse impact of neighboring 
properties. 

• Supplemental landscaping may be required as part of the Master Architectural Control 
Committee review. 

• The roof of the detached buildings shall match the roof of the house. 

NOTE: The approval of an accessory building, including a pool house, detached home office, or 
other detached building shall not be construed as approval to deviate from the single-family use 
restriction applicable to a Lot. 

Greenbelt/Open Space Lots 

Lots Adjacent to Greenbelt/Open Space Lots must comply with all of the following requirements: 

HIGHPOINTE DESIGN GUIDELINES PAGE 12 



23018808 Page 13 of 42 

1. Platted Boundary Lines. Individual homeowner lots end at the rear fence or rear property 
line. 

2. Fencing. The boundary between the Lot and the Greenbelt/Open Space Lots must be fenced 
in a manner approved in advance by the Master Architectural Control Committee. The fence 
must be six feet (6') high and be built of "black powder coated" wrought iron or other 
decorative metal of a color and style specified by the Master Architectural Control 
Committee. 

3. Gates. No gate will be permitted into a Greenbelt/Open Space Lot without the prior written 
approval of the Master Architectural Control Committee. 

4. Backyard Landscaping Requirements. Backyards must be fully sodded with at least two 3" 
caliper hardwood trees installed by the Owner. 

5. No Personal Use of Greenbelt/Open Space Lots. At no time are Greenbelt/Open Space Lots 
to be used for ingress/egress or storage.

documents.content:
room windows and kitchen windows. 

Supplemental lighting of sport courts in any form is not permitted. 

For the avoidance of doubt and in conjunction with existing restrictions regarding noise and 
nuisance considerations, activity on Sport Courts shall be limited from dawn to dusk. 

Erosion Control and Construction Regulations 

The following restrictions shall apply to all construction activities at Highpointe. Periodic 
inspections by a representative of the Master Architectural Control Committee may take place in 
order to identify non-complying construction activities. If items identified as not complying with 
the regulations are not remedied in a timely manner, fines will be levied. 

Erosion Control Installation and Maintenance 

It is the responsibility of each Owner to install erosion control measures prior to the start of 
construction and to maintain them throughout the entire construction process. 

Silt fencing installed to all applicable standards is required to be properly installed and 
maintained to protect the low sides of all disturbed areas, where stormwater will flow during 
construction. The purpose of the silt fence is to capture the sediment from the runoff and to 
permit filtered, clean water to exit the site. The Owner should anticipate that built-up sediment 
will need to be removed from the silt fence after heavy or successive rains, and that any breach in 
the fencing will need to be repaired or replaced immediately. 

If for any reason the silt fence is to be temporarily removed, please contact a representative of the 
Master Architectural Control Committee prior to the removal. 

Security 

Neither the Master Architectural Control Committee, the Association, nor the Declarant shall be 
responsible for the security of job sites during construction. 

Construction Hours 

Unless a written waiver is obtained from the Master Architectural Control Committee,

documents.content:
items shall be covered or weighted 
down to prevent wind from blowing such materials off the construction site. 

The dumping, burying or burning of trash is not permitted anywhere in Highpointe. 

It is imperative that, when moving heavy equipment around, precautions be taken to prevent 
damage to pavement, curbs, and vegetation. Crawler tractors are not to be operated on paved or 
concrete surfaces. Mud, dirt and other construction debris that is tracked off site shall be cleaned 
on a daily basis. 

Sanitary Facilities 

A temporary sanitary facility ( chemical toilet) shall be provided and maintained for the use of 
construction workers. 

Construction Parking 

Construction crews shall not park on, or otherwise use, other Lots. No construction vehicle will 
be permitted to leak oil or otherwise damage or deface any street located within the community. 

Schedule of Fines 

Periodic inspections by a representative of the Master Architectural Control Committee 
may take place in order to identify non-complying construction activities. Listed below is 
the schedule of fines which may be assessed.

Duration of Construction 

A residence shall be complete and available for occupancy on or before eighteen (18) months 
after the start of construction.

Pools, Spas and Hot Tub Plans 

Above-ground or temporary swimming pools are expressly prohibited. 

The plans and specifications for each swimming pool, spa and hot tub constructed on a Lot must 
be approved in writing and prior to construction by the Master Architectural Control Committee. 
All applications submitted to the Master Architectural Control Committee for the approval of 
plans and specifications for swimming pools, hut tubs or spas must be accompanied by the 
applicable city permits for the construction of same. Any applications submitted to the Master 
Architectural Control Committee, which do not include finalized construction permits from the 
city shall constitute an automatic rejection of the application. Above-ground or temporary 
swimming pools are prohibited. Each swimming pool constructed on a Lot must be entirely

governmental requirements. The location, color and style of the fence or enclosure must be 
approved in writing and in advance of construction by the Master Architectural Control 
Committee. The Master Architectural Control Committee may require that a swimming pool, spa 
and hot tub constructed on a Lot and associated Improvements be enclosed with a fence or 
similar structure irrespective of governmental requirements. Approval of a swimming pool, spa 
and hot tub and/or associated Improvements by the Master Architectural Control Committee will 
not constitute a determination by the Master Architectural Control Committee that the swimming 
pool, spa and hot tub and/or associated Improvements comply with governmental requirements

1. The Chandler Creek HOA swimming pool is a SWIM AT YOUR OWN RISK pool.  No lifeguards are on duty.  Children 
under the age of 16 must be accompanied by a Chandler Creek HOA resident 18 years of age or older.  This rule is 
strictly enforced. 

2. Use of any facility and/or equipment in the pool area is at your discretion. Please use caution. 

3. All Chandler Creek HOA residents are required to show their pool access pass device and a valid State of Texas ID if 
requested by a Pool Monitor.  Failure to comply may result in you being asked to leave the pool area. 

4. The access gates can only be opened with your assigned pool access device.  Gates are to remain closed/locked at all 
times.  The Pool Monitors have been instructed not to open the gate for anyone without a pool access device.  Anyone 
without a pool access device will be asked to retrieve theirs before they will be allowed to enter the pool area.  Under 
no circumstances should the gate(s) be propped open.  There is a $20 replacement fee for lost/defective pool access 
devices. 

5. One household may host up to four (4) pool guests.  All pool guests must be accompanied by a Chandler Creek HOA 
resident who remains at the pool during the guest’s visit. 

6. Chandler Creek homeowners have the authority to always enforce the current pool rules.  Conduct by any person 
deemed to be dangerous, unreasonable, or offensive (including “horseplay”) is not allowed and should be reported to 
the Pool Monitor.  Any individual disciplined repeatedly, or for serious infractions, may lose all pool privileges for the 
rest of the season. 

7. The kiddy pool is limited to children 5 years of age and younger.  Exceptions may be made for older children with injuries 
which would prevent them from safely entering the main pool.  Each child in the kiddy pool must have an adult 
supervisor;

Failure to strictly comply with the cleaning requirements will result in forfeit of security deposit.

Damages: The ROA Member will be held responsible for any damage caused by the member and or their
guests. The breach or violation of any condition set forth herein may result in the loss of the security deposit,
the imposition of liability on the ROA Member, and possible denial of future rentals of the Clubhouse.

Right of Refusal: The Association reserves the right to refuse to rent the facilities for any purpose it deems to
be detrimental to or not in the best interests of its members. It further reserves the right to refuse to rent the
facilities on any dates and at any time it deems inappropriate or inconvenient to residents of La Ventana.

La Ventana Ranch Owners Association
Pool Rules

October 1, 2023

● The LaVentana swimming pools are SWIM AT YOUR OWN RISK pools.

● The swimming pools are for the use of the ROA Members and their invited guests only.

● Pool hours are from 6 am - 10 pm. Maximum guests per household is 12.

● Pools may not be used along with a clubhouse reservation or rental. Pools remain open to residents
at all times

● Leave gates closed. DO NOT prop them open.

● Noise must be kept to a minimum and any music turned off by 9:00 pm.

● Pool furniture cannot be removed from the pool area.

● NO DIVING allowed anywhere in the pool area. No jumping off ledge between the pools.

21. Any resident may call the current HOA management company to report unsafe behavior or violations of pool rules they 
witness.  In case of an emergency, call 911.  An emergency call box is located right outside of the front pool gate in the 
courtyard. 

22. Access to the multi-purpose room is by advance reservation only. 

Miscellaneous: 

Restrooms:  The restroom fixtures are sanitized and cleaned by a private janitorial service.  The designated maintenance 
person/company is responsible for cleaning mirrors, counters, stocking hand towels, soap, emptying trashed and cleaning 
the floors and toilets.  Please be mindful of other HOA members by cleaning up after yourself when using the restrooms.  If 
the restroom should require attention, please notify the Pool Monitor on duty or call the current HOA management 
company. 

Penalties for Violation of Pool Rules: 

Depending on upon severity of offense, action taken by the HOA for violation of HOA pool rues may include one or more of 
the following: 

• 1st offense – A written warning is issued (notification of registered homeowner, parent, or guardian, when 
applicable) 

• 2nd offense – A second written warning is issued. 

• 3rd offense – Pool privileges are revoked, and pool card deactivated. 

• Criminal and civil complaints are filed when applicable: 
1. Notification of Sheriff’s Office 
2. Prosecution and/or other legal remedies

Definitions 

"Common Area" means any property and facilities that the Association owns or in which it 
otherwise holds rights or obligations.1 

"Development Area" means a part of the Development that is subject to additional restrictions set 
forth in a Development Area Declaration that applies to such property.2 

"Development Area Declaration" means, with respect to any Development Area, a separate 
instrument containing covenants, restrictions, conditions, limitations and/or easements, 
applicable to the property.3 

"Greenbelt/Open Space Lots" are portions of the Property that are designated on a Plat or in an 
instrument as property to be used as a greenbelt, open space, or a drainage easement and not for 
use as a residential lot. Open space areas may also include fenced karst feature areas, greenbelts 
and re-irrigation areas owned by the Association. Use is restricted to permitted uses only (e.g., 
use of trails established by the Association in accordance with applicable rules or trimming the 
twenty foot (20') strip behind an Owner's fence and property line in accordance with the 
Association's Rules). Otherwise, trespassing is prohibited.4

documents.content:
• 

I 

(f) No oil drilling, oil development operation, oil refining, quarrying or 
mining operations of any kind shall be permitted on the surface of the Property. No oil 
wells, tanks, tunnels, mineral excavations or shafts shall be permitted upon or in any part 
of the Property. No derrick or other structure designed for use in quarrying or boring for 
oil, natural gas or other minerals shall be erected, maintained or permitted on the 
Property. 

(g) No animals, livestock, fowl or poultry of any kind shall be raised, bred or 
kept on the Property, except that dogs, cats or other household pets may be kept for the 
purpose of providing companionship for the private family. Animals are notto be raised, 
bred or kept for commercial purposes or for food. It is the purpose of these provisions to 
restrict the use of the Property so that no person shall quarter on any part of the Property 
cows, horses, bees, pigeons, hogs, sheep, goats, guinea fowls, ducks, chickens, turkeys, 
skunks or any other animals that may interfere with the quietude, health or safety of the 
community. No more than three pets will be permitted on each Lot. Pets must be 
restrained or confined to the rear of the Owner's Lot inside a fenced area or Vlithin the 
house. It is the pet owner's responsibility to keep the Lot clean and free of pet debris. All 
animals must be properly tagged for identification and vaccinated against rabies. 

(h) No Lot or other area on the Property shall be used as a dumping ground 
for rubbish or a site for the accumulation of unsightly materials of any kind, including, 
but not limited to, broken or rusty equipment, disassembled or inoperative cars and

•

The following restrictions apply to signs advertising a political candidate or ballot item for an 
election, as described in Chapter 202: 

a. The signs may be displayed only during the period beginning 90 days before the date of the election to 
which the sign relates and ending 10 days after that election date. 

b. Only one sign for each candidate or ballot item may be displayed at each residence, and no sign may 
be larger than four feet by six feet. 

c. Each sign must be ground-mounted, and no sign may (i) contains roofing material, siding, paving 
materials, flora, one or more balloons or lights, or any other similar building, landscaping, or nonstandard 
decorative component, (ii) be attached in any way to plant material, a traffic control device, a light, a 
trailer, a vehicle, or any other existing structure or object, (iii) include the painting of architectural 
surfaces, (iv) threaten the public health or safety, (v) violate a law, (vi) contain language, graphics, or 
any display that would be offensive to the ordinary person, or (vii) be accompanied by music or other 
sounds, by streamers, or otherwise be distracting to motorists. 

d. The Association may remove a sign displayed in violation of these standards. 

12. Lights: states, " ... No holiday or occasion lighting or decorations shall be installed earlier than 
thirty (30) days prior to occasion and must be removed no later than twenty (20) days after the event. 

13. Disposal of Trash: states, "All rubbish, trash, garbage or other waste shall be kept in sanitary 
containers and out of sight of the Common Area and any street or adjacent Lot, except on days designated 
. .. for pick-up of such garbage." 

14. Animals and Livestock: states, "No more than three (3) pets shall be kept on a Lot. All pets must be 
properly tagged for identification ... No pet may be chained or leashed outside an enclosure unless being 
walked on a leash.

documents.content:
ChimneyHill Residents
IMPORTANT REMINDER REGARDING PETS
In accordance with the ChimneyHill Community Deed Restrictions, all pets must be controlled so as not to imperil the safety of others or create a nuisance, a disturbance or damage to any property with the community.  All pets must be on a leash and always controlled by the owner (NOT STAKED) while outdoors.
It is the responsibility of the pet owner to pick up and properly dispose of ALL animal waste while outdoors with their pets.  Individual Homeowner lots are not approved pet walking areas and should be avoided for animal defecation.   Approved pet walking areas are the Hiking Trail and the area north of Wimbledon Drive.   
Please be courteous to your neighbors and keep our community safe and clean by being RESPONSIBLE for your pets.

documents.content:
82.102(a) of the Texas Uniform Condominium Act; and 

 
WHEREAS the Association has voted to amend the Initial Rules and Regulations attached to the Community 
Manual (the “Rules”) as follows: 

 
1. Rule C-3 is ADDED to the Rules (“Monthly Rental Fee”) to read in its entirety as follows: 

 

“C-3.   Monthly Rental Fee.  Owners of units being leased shall pay to the Association a fee in 
the amount of $75 per month per leased unit (e.g. if an owner owns two units and leases 
one unit, the Monthly Rental Fee is $75. If the same owner leases two units, the Monthly 
Rental Fee is $150). Monthly Rental Fees are due on the 15th day of each calendar 
month.” 

 
2. Rule J-2 (“Permitted Pets”) is AMENDED and RESTATED to read in its entirety as follows: 

 

“Permitted Pets. Subject to these Rules, a resident may keep in his unit customary domesticated 
house pets, such as domesticated dogs, cats, caged birds, and aquarium fish, provided there are not 
more than two cats, or two dogs, or one cat and one dog.” 

 
3. Rule J-3 (“Prohibited Animals”) is AMENDED and RESTATED to read in its entirety as follows: 

 

“Prohibited Animals. No resident may keep a dangerous or exotic animal, trained attack dog, or 
any other animal deemed by the Board to be a potential threat to the well-being of people or other 
animals. No animal or house pet may be kept, bred, or maintained for any commercial purpose.

Document reference. Reference is hereby made to the Declaration of Condominium Regime of Macmora Cottages, 
a Condominium, filed as Document No. 2005173033 in the Official Public Records of Travis County, Texas 
(together with all amendments and supplements thereto, the “Declaration”). 

Reference is further made to the “Bylaws of Macmora Cottages HOA, Inc.”, attached as Exhibit “B” to the 
Declaration (together with all amendments and supplements thereto, the “Bylaws”).

to 
use of the greenbelt and open space lots, as well as the Highpointe trail system. 

Definitions 

"Common Area" means any property and facilities that the Association owns or in which it 
otherwise holds rights or obligations.1 

"Development Area" means a part of the Development that is subject to additional restrictions set 
forth in a Development Area Declaration that applies to such property.2 

"Development Area Declaration" means, with respect to any Development Area, a separate 
instrument containing covenants, restrictions, conditions, limitations and/or easements, 
applicable to the property.3 

"Greenbelt/Open Space Lots" are portions of the Property that are designated on a Plat or in an 
instrument as property to be used as a greenbelt, open space, or a drainage easement and not for 
use as a residential lot. Open space areas may also include fenced karst feature areas, greenbelts 
and re-irrigation areas owned by the Association. Use is restricted to permitted uses only (e.g., 
use of trails established by the Association in accordance with applicable rules or trimming the 
twenty foot (20') strip behind an Owner's fence and property line in accordance with the 
Association's Rules). Otherwise, trespassing is prohibited.4

items shall be covered or weighted 
down to prevent wind from blowing such materials off the construction site. 

The dumping, burying or burning of trash is not permitted anywhere in Highpointe. 

It is imperative that, when moving heavy equipment around, precautions be taken to prevent 
damage to pavement, curbs, and vegetation. Crawler tractors are not to be operated on paved or 
concrete surfaces. Mud, dirt and other construction debris that is tracked off site shall be cleaned 
on a daily basis. 

Sanitary Facilities 

A temporary sanitary facility ( chemical toilet) shall be provided and maintained for the use of 
construction workers. 

Construction Parking 

Construction crews shall not park on, or otherwise use, other Lots. No construction vehicle will 
be permitted to leak oil or otherwise damage or deface any street located within the community. 

Schedule of Fines 

Periodic inspections by a representative of the Master Architectural Control Committee 
may take place in order to identify non-complying construction activities. Listed below is 
the schedule of fines which may be assessed. 

HIGHPOINTE DESIGN GUIDELINES PAGE33

provide necessary service to bring the improvement into compliance, the Owner 
will be assessed the cost of repair, clean up, or service plus an additional 50% for 
time and service expended. 

Duration of Construction 

A residence shall be complete and available for occupancy on or before eighteen (18) months 
after the start of construction.

Development Restrictions 

Environmental Restrictions. Portions of Highpointe are located in areas with sensitive 
environmental features. Accordingly, there are limitations, including impervious cover 
restrictions, on development activity in the subdivision. The recorded plats for the subdivision 
are accessible at the following link: https://hayscad.com/subdivisionplats/sublisth/. The plats 
contain information about setbacks, greenbelt lots, and use restrictions. The plats should be 
reviewed along with the recorded governing documents for Highpointe. 

Use of Adjacent Lots. As a general rule, property that is adjacent to your lot that you do not own 
may not be used as an extension of your property. 

Maintaining Adjacent Lots. If your rear property line is adjacent to a greenbelt lot owned by the 
Association, in most cases you have the right to weed eat the property to a distance of up to 20 
feet beyond your rear fence and you may remove small brush and dead cedar trees. All debris, 
branches, leaves, and clippings must be removed from the property. 

Architectural Review. With few exceptions, improvements must be approved by the Association 
in writing before work commences. When in doubt, please inquire by contacting the Association. 
It is NOT better to ask for forgiveness then permission where approval is concerned. The 
governing documents, including the Design Guidelines, contain additional rules pertaining to 
use of the greenbelt and open space lots, as well as the Highpointe trail system. 

Definitions 

"Common Area" means any property and facilities that the Association owns or in which it

final until you receive a confirmation email and payment has been

3. A non-refundable rental fee of $50.00 for the first 4 hours, and $15 for each additional 
hour will be charged. 

4. The Great Room and the Conference Room are available for reservations daily from 7am 
- llpm. 

5. The amenities must be completely cleaned and all trash removed upon completion of 
your event. In the event the room requires additional cleaning and or trash removal, the 
resident's HOA account will be charged for the additional expense. 

6. Residents are responsible for any damage caused by them, or any member of their party. 

7. The association reserves the right to deny any reservation request or cancel any 
reservation at its discretion. 

8. Residents aged 21 and older may rent the amenities, and must be present during the 
entire reservation period. 

9. The following items are prohibited: 
• Pets 

• Candles 

• Smoke machines 

• Loud music 

• Tobacco products of any kind, smoking, or vaping 

The rental fee can be paid by either mailing a check to HIGHPOINTE POA, or by paying 
online (*convenience fees may apply*). 

If you are a non-profit corporation, approved by the Highpointe Board of Directors, please 
disregard the payment instructions. Your request will still be received.

PARKING AND TOWING POLICY 

1) Background. 

The streets and roadways in the subdivision are private property owned as common area 
property by the HP Property Owners Association, Inc. (the "Association"). These rules have 
been adopted by the Board of Directors (the "Board") to regulate parking activity in the 
subdivision (the "Property"). 

2) Parking Rules. 

a) To be permitted in the Property, a vehicle must be operable, and must display current 
registration and a current license tag or plate. The term "vehicles" includes automobiles,

documents.content:
Parking Rules. 

a) To be permitted in the Property, a vehicle must be operable, and must display current 
registration and a current license tag or plate. The term "vehicles" includes automobiles, 
motorcycles, motorized bikes, passenger trucks, small vans, and similar passenger 
vehicles. An "inoperable" vehicle is one that is obviously or actually not capable of being 
operated as a vehicle. Inoperable vehicle are prohibited unless stored in a garage. 

b) The following are not permitted to be parked for more than 48 hours without the Board's 
consent: trailers, boats, recreational vehicles, buses, large commercial trucks, industrial 
vehicles. 

c) No vehicle shall be parked in a manner that impedes or prevents ready access to the 
Property, driveways, or parking spaces. 

d) No vehicle may obstruct the flow of traffic, constitute a nuisance, or otherwise create a 
safety hazard. 

e) No vehicle may be parked, even temporarily, in fire lanes or in any area designated as 
"No Parking." 

f) No vehicle may obstruct or impair access to a mailbox or the delivery of mail by the U.S. 
Postal Service. 

g) No vehicle may be parked in a driveway if any portion of the vehicle extends into the 
street or creates an obstruction. 

h) No vehicle may be parked in a driveway such that the vehicle is parallel to the garage 
door. 

i) No vehicle may be abandoned (parked outside the garage) on the property. A vehicle 
that is not operable, or does not have a current inspection will be considered abandoned 
at the discretion of the Board. 



23018811 Page 70 of 73 

3) Enforcement. 

a) General. Violations of this Policy will be considered a violation of the dedicatory 
instruments governing Highpointe, but may be enforced only by the Association, acting 
through the Board. The Board may enforce this Policy in accordance with the remedies 
contained herein; however, these remedies shall not be exclusive. The Association shall

No vehicle may be parked, even 

temporarily, in fire lanes or in any area designated as "No Parking”. Vehicles parked in 

violation of these rules may be towed 

Vehicle Condition Requirements. A vehicle must be operable, and must display a 

current license tag or plate, and inspection sticker. An “inoperable” vehicle is one that is 

obviously or actually not capable of being operated as a vehicle. Each vehicle must be 

maintained and operated to minimize noise, odor, and oil emissions. No vehicle may be 

parked in the Common Elements if the Board deems it to be unsightly, inoperable, 

inappropriate, or otherwise in violation of these rules. 

Violations. A vehicle in violation of these Rules may be stickered/ticketed, wheel-locked, 

towed, or otherwise removed from the Property by the Board, at the expense of the 

vehicle's owner. The Association expressly disclaims any liability for damage to vehicles 

on which the Association exercises these remedies for Rules violations. 

C. Enforcement. 

Interpretation. In the event of any dispute regarding the effect or application of this 

policy, the interpretation of the Board of Directors (the “Board”) will be final. 

Nuisance. Every act or omission whereby any provision of this policy is violated, in 

whole or in part, is hereby declared to be a nuisance. 

Self-Help. A vehicle in violation of this policy may be towed, by or at the direction of the 

Association, at the expense of the vehicle’s owner. The Association expressly disclaims 

any liability for damage to vehicles on which the Association exercises these remedies 

for violations of this policy. 

Fines. The Association may impose fines for violation of the provisions of this policy 

pursuant to the provisions and procedures of the Association’s Fine and Enforcement 

Policy, as the same may be amended from time to time. 

D. Towing. 

Association Towing. Any vehicle parked in violation of this policy may be towed at

documents.content:
systems, if installed, shall include the following water conservation features: 

• Rain and/or moisture sensors; 

• Backflow prevention device installed in accordance with applicable state laws; 

• Pressure reducing valve and/or remote control valves for each station with flow control; 

• Pressure reducing valve, for which pressure reducing valve installed in-line at the meter 
and serving house as well as irrigation system, is acceptable; 

• Zoning of irrigation system based on plant water requirements; 

• Multiple cycle controllers with an irrigation water budget feature; 

• Minimization of overspray onto hardscapes by design, maintenance and scheduling 
practices including use of wind sensors (if reliable and available). Due to overspray, 
subsurface drip irrigation is encouraged but not required; 

• Low volume irrigation shall be installed in areas less than 10 feet wide, such as median 
strips, and parking islands; and 

• Contractors installing irrigation systems must provide system design plans to the Owner, 
and scheduling recommendations shall be posted in or near the irrigation controller box. 

Spray irrigation for each Lot shall be limited to four (4) times the foundation footprint, with a 
twenty nine thousand four hundred (29,400) square foot maximum coverage. The footprint may 
include both the house and the garage, but not the driveway or patio. 

Landscape Inspection 

The Master Architectural Control Committee may, upon the Owner's completion of the 
installation of landscaping, conduct an on-site inspection of the property to ensure compliance 
with the approved plan. 

Integrated Pest Management (1PM) 

Landscape companies providing maintenance on all common areas and individual landscapes 
must only use integrated pest management (1PM) to minimize exposure of storm water runoff to 

HIGHPOINTE DESIGN GUIDELINES PAGE26 



23018808 Page 27 of 42 

chemicals (fertilizers, herbicides and pesticides).

documents.content:
A decision by the architectural review authority 
denying an application or request by an Owner for the construction of improvements in 
the subdivision may be appealed to the Board of Directors. The Board shall hold a 
hearing not later than the 30th day after the date the Board receives the Owner's request 
for a hearing and shall notify the Owner of the date, time, and place of the hearing at 
least ten (10) days before the date of the hearing. 

HIGHPOINTE DESIGN GUIDELINES PAGE2 



23018808 Page 3 of 42 

4. Hearing Procedures. During a hearing, the Board or the designated representative of the 
Association and the Owner or the Owner's designated representative will each be 
provided with the opportunity to: (a) discuss and verify facts; (b) resolve the denial of the 
Owner's application or request for the construction of improvements; and ( c) discuss and 
address changes, if any, requested by the architectural review authority in the notice 
provided to the Owner. The Board or the Owner may request a postponement for a 
period of not more than ten (10) days. Additional postponements may be granted by 
agreement of the parties. The Board or the Owner may make an audio recording of the 
meeting, and the Board may affirm, modify, or reverse, in whole or in part, any decision 
of the architectural review authority as consistent with the Association's governing 
documents. Recording of the hearing by either party shall be disclosed before the hearing 
begins. 

Governmental Requirements 

Governmental ordinances and regulations are applicable to all Lots within Highpointe. It is the 
responsibility of each Owner to obtain all necessary permits and inspections. Compliance with 
these Design Guidelines is not a substitute for compliance with the applicable ordinances and 
regulations. Please be advised that these Design Guidelines do not list or describe each 
requirement which may be applicable to a Lot within Highpointe. Each Owner is advised to

any of the Property, except by Declarant, unless adequate provision is made for proper drainage

of drainage plans before any construction or work commences. 

Architectural Review Process 

Unless alternate Design Guidelines are adopted for additional Development Areas, these 
Design Guidelines will apply to each Development Area made subject to the Declaration. 
These Design Guidelines apply to Lots within a Development Area that are used for 
residential purposes. 

Submittals 

Requests for approval of proposed construction, landscaping, or exterior modifications must by 
made by submitting an application in the form attached hereto as Attachment 1. 

Timing 

The Master Architectural Control Committee will attempt to review all applications and 
submittals within forty-five (45) days. Please allow at least forty-five (45) days prior to 
installation or construction for the Master Architectural Control Committee to review the related 
applications. 

Responsibility for Compliance 

An applicant is responsible for ensuring that all of the applicant's representatives, including the 
applicant's architect, engineer, contractors, subcontractors, and their agents and employees, are 
aware of these Design Guidelines and all requirements imposed by the Master Architectural 
Control Committee as a condition of approval. 

Inspection 

Upon completion of all approved work, the Owner must notify the Master Architectural Control 
Committee. The Master Architectural Control Committee may inspect the work at any time to 
verify conformance with the approved submittals.

Each Owner is advised that if the Rain System Application is approved by the Master 
Architectural Control Committee, installation of the Rainwater Harvesting System must: (i) 
strictly comply with the Rain System Application; (ii) commence within thirty (30) days of 
approval; and (iii) be diligently prosecuted to completion. If the Owner fails to cause the Rain 
System Application to be installed in accordance with the approved Rain System Application, the 
Master Architectural Control Committee may require the Owner to: (i) modify the Rain System 
Application to accurately reflect the Rain System Device installed on the property; or (ii) remove 
the Rain System Device and reinstall the device in accordance with the approved Rain System 
Application. Failure to install a Rain System Device in accordance with the approved Rain 
System Application or an Owner's failure to comply with the post-approval requirements 
constitutes a violation of these guidelines and may subject the Owner to fines and penalties. Any 
requirement imposed by the Master Architectural Control Committee to resubmit a Rain System 
Application or remove and relocate a Rain System Device in accordance with the approved Rain 
System shall be at the Owner's sole cost and expense.

Approval Conditions. Unless otherwise approved in advance and in writing by the Master 
Architectural Control Committee, each Rain System Application and each Rain System Device to 
be installed in accordance therewith must comply with the following: 

• The Rain System Device must be consistent with the color scheme of the residence 
constructed on the Owner's Lot, as reasonably determined by the Master Architectural 
Control Committee.

removal of work already approved and completed or approved and in progress. It is the 

HIGHPOINTE DESIGN GUIDELINES PAGE3 



23018808 Page 4 of 42 

responsibility of each Owner to ensure that they have the most current edition of the Design 
Guidelines and every amendment thereto. 

Development Restrictions 

Environmental Restrictions. Portions of Highpointe are located in areas with sensitive 
environmental features. Accordingly, there are limitations, including impervious cover 
restrictions, on development activity in the subdivision. The recorded plats for the subdivision 
are accessible at the following link: https://hayscad.com/subdivisionplats/sublisth/. The plats 
contain information about setbacks, greenbelt lots, and use restrictions. The plats should be 
reviewed along with the recorded governing documents for Highpointe. 

Use of Adjacent Lots. As a general rule, property that is adjacent to your lot that you do not own 
may not be used as an extension of your property. 

Maintaining Adjacent Lots. If your rear property line is adjacent to a greenbelt lot owned by the 
Association, in most cases you have the right to weed eat the property to a distance of up to 20 
feet beyond your rear fence and you may remove small brush and dead cedar trees. All debris, 
branches, leaves, and clippings must be removed from the property. 

Architectural Review. With few exceptions, improvements must be approved by the Association 
in writing before work commences. When in doubt, please inquire by contacting the Association. 
It is NOT better to ask for forgiveness then permission where approval is concerned. The 
governing documents, including the Design Guidelines, contain additional rules pertaining to 
use of the greenbelt and open space lots, as well as the Highpointe trail system. 

Definitions 

"Common Area" means any property and facilities that the Association owns or in which it

documents.content:
nor the Declarant shall be 
responsible for the security of job sites during construction. 

Construction Hours 

Unless a written waiver is obtained from the Master Architectural Control Committee, 
construction may take place only during the following hours: Monday through Friday from 7:00 
a.m. until 7:00 p.m., and on Saturdays and Sundays from 9:00 a.m. until 6:00 p.m. 

Noise, Animals, Children 

The use of radios, tape and CD players must be restrained so as not to be heard on an adjoining 
Lot or street. 

HIGHPOINTE DESIGN GUIDELINES PAGE 32 



23018808 Page 33 of 42 

Contractors and subcontractors may not bring dogs or children under 16 years of age to 
construction sites. 

Material and Equipment Storage 

All construction materials and equipment shall be neatly stacked, properly covered and secured. 
Any storage of materials or equipment shall be the Owner's responsibility and at their risk. 
Owners may not disturb, damage or trespass on other Lots or adjacent property. 

Insurance 

The Master Architectural Control Committee requires an Owner to procure adequate commercial 
liability insurance during construction naming the Association, the Declarant and the Master 
Architectural Control Committee as additional insureds, in an amount to be determined, from 
time to time by the Master Architectural Control Committee. 

Site Cleanliness 

During the construction period, each construction site shall be kept neat and shall be properly 
policed to prevent it from becoming an eyesore. 

Owners shall provide a container for debris and shall clean up all trash and debris on the 
construction site on a daily basis. Trash and debris shall be removed from each construction site 
on a timely basis. Lightweight material, packaging and other items shall be covered or weighted 
down to prevent wind from blowing such materials off the construction site. 

The dumping, burying or burning of trash is not permitted anywhere in Highpointe.

documents.content:
and service expended. 

Duration of Construction 

A residence shall be complete and available for occupancy on or before eighteen (18) months 
after the start of construction. 

Plan Submittals 

New residential home construction within Highpointe will utilize a two-stage review process. No 
Improvements may be commenced until the Owner has received a written II Approval" from the 
Master Architectural Control Committee. 

PLAN BOOK, MATERIAL AND LANDSCAPE REVIEW 

The applicant must first submit for approval plans for the home designs to be offered in the 
neighborhood including the exterior elevations and landscaping associated with each plan. 

The Plan Book, Material, and Landscaping Review will require the submission of the following 
information: 

• Floorplans 
• Elevations of all sides of each home indicating 

Roof pitch 
Roof peak height above the foundation 
Exterior materials- walls, roof, chimney 
Window specifications 
Chimney cap materials/design 
Heated/air conditioned square footage of each floor and the total heated/air 
conditioned square footage 

HIGHPOINTE DESIGN GUIDELINES PAGE 34 



23018808 Page 35 of 42 

• Material samples, including stone samples (colors and patterns), mortar colors, stucco 
colors, trim colors, roof materials and colors, and window materials and colors must be 
approved in advance by the Master Architectural Control Committee. The Master 
Architectural Control Committee reserves the right to request samples of all materials. 
PLEASE BE ADVISED THAT PLAN BOOK AND MATERIAL REVIEW IS NOT 
FINAL APPROVAL. SPECIFICALLY, MATERIAL TO BE INCORPORATED INTO A 
RESIDENCE OR IMPROVEMENT IS NOT APPROVED FOR USE ON A 
PARTICULAR RESIDENCE OR IMPROVEMENTS UNTIL THE FINAL PLAN 
REVIEW FOR THE RESIDENCE AND/OR IMPROVEMENT HAS BEEN 
SUBMITTED TO AND APPROVED BY THE MASTER ARCHITECTURAL 
CONTROL COMMITTEE. 

• Sample Landscaping Plan 
General boundaries of turf areas with type of turf noted 
General locations of all proposed plants

documents.content:
1
Hello, Parkside at Slaughter Creek!

We established a new board of directors in April 2024 and we are very excited to make our community a better place. In this letter, you will find some helpful information. Please read it fully and reach out if you have any questions. Thank you!


Parkside at Slaughter Creek
Friendly Reminders…

All owners and tenants must comply with the Covenants, Conditions & Restrictions (CC&Rs) of the Parkside at Slaughter Creek Home Owner’s Association. Below are a few friendly and simple reminders.

The CC&Rs can be reviewed via our HOA portal. Please review the CC&Rs and the friendly reminders below to avoid any violations, fines, etc. Owners are responsible for all violations related to their guests, occupants, or tenants. We appreciate your cooperation.

1. Residential Utilization:  All homes are for single-family residence use only.

2. Exterior Improvements:  Reach out to Parkside at Slaughter Creek’s Architectural Committee via our HOA portal before starting any improvement work.

3. Landscaping:  All yards shall be maintained. Grass, trees, hedges, fences, and plants should be in a neat and attractive condition. Maintenance shall include regular mowing, edging, weeding of plant beds, weed control, and bush/tree trimming. Front yards shall be sodded with grass. If your yard is just weeds or dirt, you are not in compliance with the CC&Rs.

4. Trees:  Diseased/dead plants or trees must be removed. Austin City Code states trees need to be 14 feet above the street and 8 feet above the sidewalk. Please trim your trees.

5. HOA Dues:  HOA Dues are semi-annual (January 1st and July 1st) and are mandatory. If dues are not paid, late fees, interest, and legal fees can and will be added to your account. If you have any questions regarding your account, please contact Vangie Bocanegra with PioneerBeck (contact info below).

6. Disturbances:  Owners and occupants shall not make loud or objectionable noise.

Association Management Agreement 

 
 
 
  

THIS AGREEMENT is entered into as of   _______________________, by and between Parkside at Slaughter 
Creek Homeowners Association, a Texas Corporation, hereinafter referred to as the “ASSOCIATION" and Octus, Inc., 
DBA PIONEER/BECK Community Association Management, hereinafter referred to as the “AGENT". 
 

 

DEFINITIONS 
 

Physical Property Address:   Slaughter and IH 35 

Registered Agent Address:   611 S Congress #510, Austin, Texas 78704 

 
 "Common Area" shall have the meaning set forth in the definitions of the Declaration. On the date hereof the 
Common Area consists of the following: 
 
All of the common area described further in the deed restrictions, by-laws and covenants that govern and apply to the 
association and are made a part of this agreement and attached hereto. 
 
 "Owner” shall mean and refer to each record owner of a fee simple title interest in and to any unit in the Parkside 
at Slaughter Creek HOA except the Common Area. Each contract Purchaser of a fee simple title interest in any lot 
(except the Common Area) shall be deemed an Owner for the purpose hereof. 
 
 
 

RECITALS 

 

 Under the Declaration and under the Bylaws of the Association, the Board of Directors of the Association, 
through its officers, are expressly authorized and empowered to engage the services of a Managing Agent who shall 
manage, operate and maintain the Common Area and any Areas that are maintained by the Association. 
 
 The Board of Directors, on behalf of the Association desire to employ Agent to manage, operate and maintain 
the Common Area and Maintained Area in accordance with the Declaration, the Bylaws of Association, and any 
applicable Rules and Regulations of Association, and as more fully set forth hereinafter. 
 
 IT IS AGREED: 
 
 1. The Association employs the Agent exclusively to manage the common and maintained areas for a period

applicable Rules and Regulations of Association, and as more fully set forth hereinafter.

documents.content:
1
Hello, Parkside at Slaughter Creek!

We established a new board of directors in April 2024 and we are very excited to make our community a better place. In this letter, you will find some helpful information. Please read it fully and reach out if you have any questions. Thank you!


Parkside at Slaughter Creek
Friendly Reminders…

All owners and tenants must comply with the Covenants, Conditions & Restrictions (CC&Rs) of the Parkside at Slaughter Creek Home Owner’s Association. Below are a few friendly and simple reminders.

The CC&Rs can be reviewed via our HOA portal. Please review the CC&Rs and the friendly reminders below to avoid any violations, fines, etc. Owners are responsible for all violations related to their guests, occupants, or tenants. We appreciate your cooperation.

1. Residential Utilization:  All homes are for single-family residence use only.

2. Exterior Improvements:  Reach out to Parkside at Slaughter Creek’s Architectural Committee via our HOA portal before starting any improvement work.

3. Landscaping:  All yards shall be maintained. Grass, trees, hedges, fences, and plants should be in a neat and attractive condition. Maintenance shall include regular mowing, edging, weeding of plant beds, weed control, and bush/tree trimming. Front yards shall be sodded with grass. If your yard is just weeds or dirt, you are not in compliance with the CC&Rs.

4. Trees:  Diseased/dead plants or trees must be removed. Austin City Code states trees need to be 14 feet above the street and 8 feet above the sidewalk. Please trim your trees.

5. HOA Dues:  HOA Dues are semi-annual (January 1st and July 1st) and are mandatory. If dues are not paid, late fees, interest, and legal fees can and will be added to your account. If you have any questions regarding your account, please contact Vangie Bocanegra with PioneerBeck (contact info below).

6. Disturbances:  Owners and occupants shall not make loud or objectionable noise.

The HOA portal gives you access to everything you need as a resident of Parkside at 
Slaughter Creek. If you are not registered with our HOA portal, please follow the 
instructions below: 
 

● Go to www.pioneeraustin.com 
● Click on “LINKS” on the top 
● Click on “PIONEERATX” 
● If you have never registered before, click “Need to Register?” 
● On the next page enter your zip code, 78747 
● Click on “I live in Parkside at Slaughter Creek, Austin, TX” 
● Select one of the following: 

“I am an owner”  
“I am a new owner” 
“I am a renter” 

● Enter your information to become registered! Welcome to our HOA portal! 
 
 

 

Board Members and Property Manager 
 
Monique Johnson-Jones, President 
Eddie Cox, Vice President 
David De La Pena, Treasurer 
Stacy Klaus, Secretary 
Vangie Bocanegra, Property Manager (PioneerBeck)

6. Disturbances:  Owners and occupants shall not make loud or objectionable 

noise. Loud music, fireworks, and excessive dog barking are not permitted in any 
home or the common areas. 

 
7.  Parking/Vehicles:  Automobiles shall be parked in your driveway and garage. 

Your vehicle should not block the sidewalk. Additional vehicles may be parked in 
the street but for no more than 24 hours. Repair work on automobiles in 
driveways or streets is not permitted. No mobile home, trailer of any kind, boat, 
camper, tent, or similar structure shall be kept, placed, maintained, parked, 
constructed, reconstructed, or repaired. A vehicle without current license tags 
and/or inspection stickers will be considered a junk car and will be towed away at 
the owner’s expense. 

 
8. Exterior Debris:  No one may hang garments, leave rugs, and/or other material 

in or on the curb/street. Please dispose of your personal items. 
 

9. Trash Cans:  All trash cans (brown, blue, and green) may not be placed or 
stored in plain sight. All containers must be stored out of view at all times. 

 
10.  Animals:  All dogs must be kept on a leash at all times, including on the trail. 

Please pick up after your dog/animals.

Parkside at Slaughter Creek
2024 Annual meeting Script
April 29, 2024
Time: 6:00 p.m.

1. Roll Call and Certifying Proxies - Introductions
	Monique Johnson, President
	Eddie Cox, Vice President/Treasurer
	Vangie Bocanegra, Property Manager with Pioneer Beck

	Have each owner on the call introduce themselves. Just state their name and address.  I will handle the 	sign in/confirm we have quorum.  We must have a quorum to conduct business.  

	Everyone will be muted except for the board members.  There will be an owner’s open
forum    and every owner will have an opportunity to speak.  Please hold your 	questions until then.

2. Proof of Meeting Notice- Vangie Bocanegra confirms that the annual meeting notices were mailed out per the bylaws.  A copy was also posted on the portal.

3. Approval of 2023 Minutes- Review and approve last year’s annual meeting minutes.  Please make a motion to approve___________. Seconded________
	All in favor.

4. President report/Old & New Business
A. Just a reminder/Community Spring Community Garage Sale. -May 4, 2024.
	You can install signs, but all signs must be removed and picked up after the event. 
	
B. Just a reminder that all Exterior Improvements must be approved prior to any work being done by the Architectural Control Committee.

C. Seeking volunteers to serve on the Architectural Committee and Landscape Committee. If you are interested, please contact Vangie Bocanegra at Pioneer Beck.

D. No exterior speakers, horns whistles, bells, or other sound devices (other than security devices used exclusively for security purposes) shall be located, used, or placed on any of the Property No noise or other Nuisance shall be permitted to be offensive.

E. Please make sure all pets are always on a leash, please also pick up after your pet.

F. Playscape

G. Yard maintenance

H. Trailers/vehicles

I. If you see any suspicious activity, please call 311. All emergencies, call 911.

2 

 
6. Disturbances:  Owners and occupants shall not make loud or objectionable 

noise. Loud music, fireworks, and excessive dog barking are not permitted in any 
home or the common areas. 

 
7.  Parking/Vehicles:  Automobiles shall be parked in your driveway and garage. 

Your vehicle should not block the sidewalk. Additional vehicles may be parked in 
the street but for no more than 24 hours. Repair work on automobiles in 
driveways or streets is not permitted. No mobile home, trailer of any kind, boat, 
camper, tent, or similar structure shall be kept, placed, maintained, parked, 
constructed, reconstructed, or repaired. A vehicle without current license tags 
and/or inspection stickers will be considered a junk car and will be towed away at 
the owner’s expense. 

 
8. Exterior Debris:  No one may hang garments, leave rugs, and/or other material 

in or on the curb/street. Please dispose of your personal items. 
 

9. Trash Cans:  All trash cans (brown, blue, and green) may not be placed or 
stored in plain sight. All containers must be stored out of view at all times. 

 
10.  Animals:  All dogs must be kept on a leash at all times, including on the trail. 

Please pick up after your dog/animals. 
 

 
Board Members and Property Manager 

 
Monique Johnson-Jones, President 
Eddie Cox, Vice President 
David De La Pena, Treasurer 
Stacy Klaus, Secretary 
Vangie Bocanegra, Property Manager (PioneerBeck) 
Phone: 512-855-6117 
Email: vangie@pioneerbeck.com 

mailto:vangie@pioneerbeck.com

13 

 
Association Management Agreement 

 
 
 
  

THIS AGREEMENT is entered into as of   _______________________, by and between Parkside at Slaughter 
Creek Homeowners Association, a Texas Corporation, hereinafter referred to as the “ASSOCIATION" and Octus, Inc., 
DBA PIONEER/BECK Community Association Management, hereinafter referred to as the “AGENT". 
 

 

DEFINITIONS 
 

Physical Property Address:   Slaughter and IH 35 

Registered Agent Address:   611 S Congress #510, Austin, Texas 78704 

 
 "Common Area" shall have the meaning set forth in the definitions of the Declaration. On the date hereof the 
Common Area consists of the following: 
 
All of the common area described further in the deed restrictions, by-laws and covenants that govern and apply to the 
association and are made a part of this agreement and attached hereto. 
 
 "Owner” shall mean and refer to each record owner of a fee simple title interest in and to any unit in the Parkside 
at Slaughter Creek HOA except the Common Area. Each contract Purchaser of a fee simple title interest in any lot 
(except the Common Area) shall be deemed an Owner for the purpose hereof. 
 
 
 

RECITALS 

 

 Under the Declaration and under the Bylaws of the Association, the Board of Directors of the Association, 
through its officers, are expressly authorized and empowered to engage the services of a Managing Agent who shall 
manage, operate and maintain the Common Area and any Areas that are maintained by the Association. 
 
 The Board of Directors, on behalf of the Association desire to employ Agent to manage, operate and maintain 
the Common Area and Maintained Area in accordance with the Declaration, the Bylaws of Association, and any 
applicable Rules and Regulations of Association, and as more fully set forth hereinafter. 
 
 IT IS AGREED: 
 
 1. The Association employs the Agent exclusively to manage the common and maintained areas for a period

Association Management Agreement



	
THIS AGREEMENT is entered into as of   _______________________, by and between Parkside at Slaughter Creek Homeowners Association, a Texas Corporation, hereinafter referred to as the “ASSOCIATION" and Octus, Inc., DBA PIONEER/BECK Community Association Management, hereinafter referred to as the “AGENT".


DEFINITIONS

Physical Property Address:   Slaughter and IH 35
Registered Agent Address:   611 S Congress #510, Austin, Texas 78704

	"Common Area" shall have the meaning set forth in the definitions of the Declaration. On the date hereof the Common Area consists of the following:

All of the common area described further in the deed restrictions, by-laws and covenants that govern and apply to the association and are made a part of this agreement and attached hereto.

	"Owner” shall mean and refer to each record owner of a fee simple title interest in and to any unit in the Parkside at Slaughter Creek HOA except the Common Area. Each contract Purchaser of a fee simple title interest in any lot (except the Common Area) shall be deemed an Owner for the purpose hereof.



RECITALS

	Under the Declaration and under the Bylaws of the Association, the Board of Directors of the Association, through its officers, are expressly authorized and empowered to engage the services of a Managing Agent who shall manage, operate and maintain the Common Area and any Areas that are maintained by the Association.

	The Board of Directors, on behalf of the Association desire to employ Agent to manage, operate and maintain the Common Area and Maintained Area in accordance with the Declaration, the Bylaws of Association, and any applicable Rules and Regulations of Association, and as more fully set forth hereinafter.

	IT IS AGREED:

STATE OF TEXAS      §

COUNTY OF TRAVIS §  
  
Pursuant to the Bylaws of Parkside at Slaughter Creek Owners Association, Inc. (referred to as “Association”) and 

the Declaration of Protective Covenants, the Directors of Parkside at Slaughter Creek Owners Association, Inc., a 

Texas non-profit corporation, consent to the adoption of the following resolution:  
  

  
RE:    Violation Enforcement Policy  
  
WHEREAS:  
  

1. The Board of Directors is empowered to enforce the covenants, conditions and restrictions of the 

Covenants, Bylaws and any rules and regulations of the Association.  

2. It is the Board's duty to use its best efforts to assure that said enforcement occurs  
  
BE RESOLVED THAT:   

  

1. The Board of Directors hereby adopts this Violation Enforcement Policy to establish equitable policies for the  

Association in compliance with the Chapter 209 of the Texas Property Code, titled the “Texas Residential 

Property Owners Protection Act,” as it may be amended (the “Act”).  To the extent any provision within this 

policy is in conflict the Act or any other applicable law, such provision shall be modified to comply with the 

applicable law.   

2. All rules of the Association shall be enforced   

3. The Violation and Fine Schedule (attached) shall be the Association’s policy of enforcement.

documents.content:
1
Hello, Parkside at Slaughter Creek!

We established a new board of directors in April 2024 and we are very excited to make our community a better place. In this letter, you will find some helpful information. Please read it fully and reach out if you have any questions. Thank you!


Parkside at Slaughter Creek
Friendly Reminders…

All owners and tenants must comply with the Covenants, Conditions & Restrictions (CC&Rs) of the Parkside at Slaughter Creek Home Owner’s Association. Below are a few friendly and simple reminders.

The CC&Rs can be reviewed via our HOA portal. Please review the CC&Rs and the friendly reminders below to avoid any violations, fines, etc. Owners are responsible for all violations related to their guests, occupants, or tenants. We appreciate your cooperation.

1. Residential Utilization:  All homes are for single-family residence use only.

2. Exterior Improvements:  Reach out to Parkside at Slaughter Creek’s Architectural Committee via our HOA portal before starting any improvement work.

3. Landscaping:  All yards shall be maintained. Grass, trees, hedges, fences, and plants should be in a neat and attractive condition. Maintenance shall include regular mowing, edging, weeding of plant beds, weed control, and bush/tree trimming. Front yards shall be sodded with grass. If your yard is just weeds or dirt, you are not in compliance with the CC&Rs.

4. Trees:  Diseased/dead plants or trees must be removed. Austin City Code states trees need to be 14 feet above the street and 8 feet above the sidewalk. Please trim your trees.

5. HOA Dues:  HOA Dues are semi-annual (January 1st and July 1st) and are mandatory. If dues are not paid, late fees, interest, and legal fees can and will be added to your account. If you have any questions regarding your account, please contact Vangie Bocanegra with PioneerBeck (contact info below).

6. Disturbances:  Owners and occupants shall not make loud or objectionable noise.

The HOA portal gives you access to everything you need as a resident of Parkside at 
Slaughter Creek. If you are not registered with our HOA portal, please follow the 
instructions below: 
 

● Go to www.pioneeraustin.com 
● Click on “LINKS” on the top 
● Click on “PIONEERATX” 
● If you have never registered before, click “Need to Register?” 
● On the next page enter your zip code, 78747 
● Click on “I live in Parkside at Slaughter Creek, Austin, TX” 
● Select one of the following: 

“I am an owner”  
“I am a new owner” 
“I am a renter” 

● Enter your information to become registered! Welcome to our HOA portal!

documents.content:
February 4, 2019 

Dear ACC Committee: 

As approved by the Board/ACC on February 4, 2019, we will be moving forward with the ACC One Touch 
Process. Below are the requests agreed upon by Parkside at Slaughter Creek Owners Association, Inc. that will 
be auto approved or denied per the DCCR’s, designer guidelines, and HOA guidelines: 

General Property Maintenance – general repairs and maintenance of the exterior of the home 
> Door Replacement – same as existing, no change 
> Fence Replacement – same as existing, no change 
> Roof Replacement – same as existing, no change 
> Exterior Paint Maintenance – same as existing no change 
> Window Replacement – same as existing, no change 

Common Requests 
> Roof-Mounted Solar Panels & Solar Panel Shingles – rear/side location, must provide 10% documentation  
> Solar Screens 
> Satellite Dishes 
> Security Lights/Low Voltage Lighting – must be aimed into, and not outside of, property lines; must show 
dark sky compliance 
> Flag Poles/Flags – meets Flag Display Guideline and Texas Property Code 202.011, not in any easement area 
> Gutters – painted to match the residence trim 
> Security Cameras 

All improvements will be considered approved by the Parkside at Slaughter Creek Owners Association, Inc. The 
documentation for each improvement will be required as standard and all files will be accessible on the CINC 
website for review at all times. The approval permit will be completed at Spectrum Association Management 
and signed by the ACC Coordinator for the Parkside at Slaughter Creek Owners Association, Inc. as its agent. If 
you have a blank fillable soft copy of this form, please send it to your ACC Coordinator to add to the approval 
files. 

If you would like to add or remove improvements from the list above, please do not hesitate to share them 
with your ACC Coordinator and they will adjust the file accordingly. 

Regards, 

Andrew Hale
