PARKSIDE AT SLAUGHTER CREEK OWNERS ASSOCIATION, INC. 
Board Meeting 

March 18, 2024 
Meeting Time: 6:00 p.m.  

Virtual Meeting 
Join the meeting: https://meetings.dialpad.com/room/vengelina 

Dial in number: 209-653-3763 
PIN: No PIN needed 

AGENDA 
 

I. Call Meeting to Order 
 
 

II. New Business 
A. Vote to use the previously adopted and recorded Enforcement Policy outlined in 

the Parkside at Slaughter Creek HOA Covenants, Conditions and Restrictions (CC& 

Rs) as the newly adopted rules to be filed again on record as the policy of the HOA.  
B. Vote on Bylaw Amendment to increase the board to Five (5). 
C. Update on the trail/greenbelt clean up. 
 
 

III. Financial Update 
 

IV. Homeowner Forum (limited to 3-5 minutes, per homeowner. The Board 
reserves the right to limit and/or suspend questions from the agenda at its sole 
discretion.)  
 

V. Executive Session 
 
VI.  Adjourn

_____________________________________________________________________________________

5.  Notice to Applicant:

The authority of the Architectural Control Committee ("ACC") is derived from the Declaration of Covenants, Conditions and Restrictions ("CCRs").

IMPORTANT:  No work should be commenced until written approval is received from the ACC.

Applicant acknowledges that all improvements must be constructed in accordance with the design guidelines contained in the CCRs in addition to any guidelines or rules adopted by the Association or ACC from time to time.  All improvements must be constructed in accordance with the laws, rules, regulations, and building codes of governmental authorities having jurisdiction.  Approval of this application does not constitute approval by any governmental authority, nor does it constitute a building permit.

Approval of this application does not give Applicant the right to enter upon the property of any other owner or the common area in order to perform the construction contemplated by this application.

Applicant certifies that the information contained herein is true and correct to the best knowledge and belief of Applicant.

__________________________________________________     ____________

Applicant Signature                                                                            Date

SUBMIT THIS APPLICATION TO:  

Parkside at Slaughter Creek
C/o Pioneer Real Estate-Judy Wilcox
611 S Congress Ave # 510

Austin, Texas 78704

Fax:  512-443-3757 or email to:

judy@pioneeraustin.com 

The application will be routed to the Parkside at Slaughter Creek Architectural Control Committee for consideration

Please allow 2-4 weeks for processing applications. 

If you are not contacted within 15 working days from submittal, an email follow-up to the property manager is recommended.  

For ACC Use Only

5/30/2024
Project Ref:  9901 Big Boggy Trail/Parkside at Slaughter Creek
Lauren Romero
9901 Big Boggy Trail
Austin, TX 78747
Laurenintexas@gmail.com
Dear Lauren,
I am happy to inform you that the Parkside at Slaughter Creek Architectural Committee has granted approval for your roof replacement, with the following stipulations:

· The construction must adhere to the submitted plans.  Any changes will require additional review.
· Kindly submit a $50.00 review fee, which will be billed to your HOA account.

The approval is contingent upon compliance with the specifications set forth in the approved application and the project must be completed within the time limit established within the governing documents. If your changes or addition requires a county, city, or state permit, it is the responsibility of the homeowner to obtain this before starting the project.

Please be advised that Parkside at Slaughter Creek does not warrant any improvements including structural design, functional concern, and building code compliance.

Please retain this letter in your files. If you have any questions regarding this matter, please contact our office at 512-447-4496 or email us at association@pioneerbeck.com
On Behalf of the ACC Committee

Sincerely,

Judy Wilcox

Pioneer/Beck Community Association Management

documents.content:
February 4, 2019 

Dear ACC Committee: 

As approved by the Board/ACC on February 4, 2019, we will be moving forward with the ACC One Touch 
Process. Below are the requests agreed upon by Parkside at Slaughter Creek Owners Association, Inc. that will 
be auto approved or denied per the DCCR’s, designer guidelines, and HOA guidelines: 

General Property Maintenance – general repairs and maintenance of the exterior of the home 
> Door Replacement – same as existing, no change 
> Fence Replacement – same as existing, no change 
> Roof Replacement – same as existing, no change 
> Exterior Paint Maintenance – same as existing no change 
> Window Replacement – same as existing, no change 

Common Requests 
> Roof-Mounted Solar Panels & Solar Panel Shingles – rear/side location, must provide 10% documentation  
> Solar Screens 
> Satellite Dishes 
> Security Lights/Low Voltage Lighting – must be aimed into, and not outside of, property lines; must show 
dark sky compliance 
> Flag Poles/Flags – meets Flag Display Guideline and Texas Property Code 202.011, not in any easement area 
> Gutters – painted to match the residence trim 
> Security Cameras 

All improvements will be considered approved by the Parkside at Slaughter Creek Owners Association, Inc. The 
documentation for each improvement will be required as standard and all files will be accessible on the CINC 
website for review at all times. The approval permit will be completed at Spectrum Association Management 
and signed by the ACC Coordinator for the Parkside at Slaughter Creek Owners Association, Inc. as its agent. If 
you have a blank fillable soft copy of this form, please send it to your ACC Coordinator to add to the approval 
files. 

If you would like to add or remove improvements from the list above, please do not hesitate to share them 
with your ACC Coordinator and they will adjust the file accordingly. 

Regards, 

Andrew Hale

Description of the job: 6’ FT PRIVACY FENCE PINK AREA AS REQUEST

2022                       

Name: Ps Property Management 
Job  

Name:
Cooper lane  privacy fence 

Street 
Address: 1490 Rusk Rd  Ste . 301

Job 
Location:

City, ST, Zip:
Round Rock Tx 7665 Claim#:

Phone: 512-251-6122 Property:
Sweetwater gleen 

1. Remove existing about 5,800 LF fence on all  homes on the property as request. 
2. Install new fences to match the existing layout including 65 stardar size gate. 
3. Install new 2 3/8  galvanized metal post set on 18’ to 24 inch deep concrete. 
4. Install 3- 2x4 weather shield  runners instead of two. 
5. install 6” wide cedar pickets attached with 6 crews each. 
6. Clean, haul and disposal all trash related to the job. 

NOTE : ALL NEW GALVANIZED HARDWARE WILL BE INSTALL ALONG WITH THE METAL POST AND 
ALL PICKET WILL BE ATTACH WITH POLYMER -PLATED  SCREWS  (NO NAILS ) 
NOTE : APPLY CLEAR COAT ON BOUTH SIDES OF THE FENCE WILL ADD $33.000.00 TO THE 
ORIGINAL BID 

                                                                                                     Total job $ 160.000.00 
                                                                                           Down payment $ 80.000.00 
                                                                                             Final payment $ 80,000.00
All Material is guaranteed to be as specified.  All work to be completed in a workmanlike manner according to standard practices.  Any 
alteration or deviation from the above specifications involving extra costs will be executed only upon written orders, and will become an 
extra charge over and above the estimate.  
All agreements contingent upon strikes, accidents or delays beyond our control.

3.	Use Easements.  The Parties hereby acknowledge that the Boundary Fencing is generally constructed along the common boundary between the Cooper Lane Regime and Village Regime, but does or may encroach in certain areas on both the Village Regime and Cooper Lane Regime, such that portion(s) of the Village Regime is within the fenced area of the Cooper Lane Regime and/or portion(s) of the Cooper Lane Regime is within the fenced area of the Village Regime (each, an “Encroachment Area”).  Where applicable, Village HOA and Declarant do hereby GIVE, GRANT, and CONVEY unto Cooper Lane HOA, for the benefit of Cooper Lane HOA and the Cooper Lane Permittees, a non-exclusive access and use easement on, over, and across the Encroachment Area, but only to the extent that the Boundary Fencing encroaches upon the Village Regime.  Likewise, where applicable, Cooper Lane HOA does hereby GIVE, GRANT, and CONVEY unto Village HOA and any current and future owners of the Village Burdened Units, a non-exclusive use easement on, over, and across the Encroachment Area, but only to the extent that the Boundary Fencing encroaches upon the Cooper Lane Regime.

4.	Maintenance Fee.  In consideration for the obligation of Cooper Lane HOA to maintain, repair, or replace the Boundary Fencing, Village HOA shall pay to Cooper Lane HOA an annual fee equal to [_____________________ and ______ Dollars ($__________.__)] (the “Maintenance Fee”).  The Maintenance Fee will be increased annually based on the lesser of the following: (i) three (3%) percent of the prior year’s Maintenance Fee; or (ii) the percentage change in the Consumer Price Index (“CPI”) for all Urban ConsumersU.S.

Scope of Work
We would like to thank you for giving us the opportunity to earn your business. We've
included a detailed estimate of your project along with as many details as possible

If you have any questions about our bid, material, service, pricing or any other question,
please don't hesitate to call. We have many price points that fits most budgets. 

We've been building all types of fences since 2006. We build residential & commercial, wood
privacy of just about any style, ornamental iron, chainlink, custom gates, gate operator
installation, decks & pergolas. We always use screws as fasteners, not nails. We use
premium quality wood on all wood projects, superior quality ornamental iron (wrought iron) &
buy from the national suppliers for consistency and lower prices. Not the big box stores,
actual fence suppliers.

We built over 200,000 of fence in 2022 and our combined years of fence experience is near
150 years. We are the Premier fence company of Central Texas if you want it built right and to
last.

Full Fence

documents.content:
Fencing; provided that in no instance shall such entry unreasonably interfere with the use of the Village Regime for residential purposes.
1. Maintenance Obligations and Self-Help Easement.  
(a) Cooper Lane HOA shall be responsible, at its sole cost and expense, for maintaining the Boundary Fencing in good condition and repair (reasonable wear and tear excepted), free of trash and other debris, in accordance with all applicable laws, ordinances, regulations and codes.  With respect to any portion of the fence that is wood, the same shall be repainted or re-stained every five years (or more often if reasonably required due to wear and tear).  Cooper Lane HOA shall be responsible for any required replacement of the Boundary Fencing at Cooper Lane HOA’s sole costs and expense, aside from the annual Maintenance Fee (defined below) paid by Village HOA in accordance with Section 4 below, subject to the indemnity obligations in Section 7 below.  If replacement of any portion of the Boundary Fencing is required, Cooper Lane shall reconstruct and reinstall the Boundary Fencing in its originally built location, unless otherwise approved in writing by the Village HOA.  Furthermore, Cooper Lane HOA shall not make any structural modifications to or change the color of the Boundary Fencing without the advance written consent of the Village HOA.

(b) If Cooper Lane HOA causes damage to any improvement, landscaping or other portion of the Village Regime, whether or not such damage is within the Easement Area, as a result of Cooper Lane HOA’s entrance thereupon or Cooper Lane HOA’s performance of its obligations contained herein, Cooper Lane HOA shall restore such improvement or property to the condition which existed prior to any such damage, within a reasonable period of time not to exceed thirty (30) days after the date Cooper Lane HOA is notified in writing of the damage by Village HOA.

documents.content:
II. INITIAL RULES & REGULATIONS 

These Initial Rules & Regulations are established by MILESTONE COMMUNITY BUILDERS, LLC, a 
Texas limited liability company, for the benefit of the Cooper Lane Condominium Community, Inc., a 
Texas non-profit corporation (the "Association"). These Community Rules are the "Rules" defined in 
Article 1 of the Declaration of Condominium Regime for Cooper Lane Condominiums, recorded as 
Document Number 2015178238 in the Official Public Records of Travis County, Texas, as it may be 
amended (the "Declaration"). 

These Rules are in addition to the provisions of the Declaration and Bylaws. By owning or 
occupying a Unit, each Owner and Resident agrees to abide by these Rules and to comply with the 
obligations of Owners and Residents under the Declaration and Bylaws of the Association. 

Words and phrases defined in the Declaration have the same meaning when used in these 
Rules. In the event of a conflict between Documents, the hierarchy of authority is as follows: 
Declaration (highest), Bylaws, and these Rules (lowest). The Association's board of directors is 
empowered to interpret, enforce, amend, and repeal these Rules. 

A. COMPLIANCE 

A-1. Compliance. Each Owner will comply with the provisions of these Rules, the other Documents, 
and policies adopted by the Board to supplement these Rules, as any of these may be revised 
from time to time. Each Owner, additionally, is responsible for compliance with the Documents 
by the Residents of his Unit, and his or their respective relatives, invitees, tenants, agents, 
employees, or contractors. If a Rule requires or prohibits conduct by an "Owner" or "Resident," 
each of those terms are deemed to include the other, and applies to all persons for whom an 
Owner or Resident is responsible. Any question regarding these rules should be referred to the 
Association The Association has the right to enforce these Rules against any person on the 
Property. 

DRAFTER'S DICTUM

the Association if the Owner desires to receive email communications from the 
Association. Failure to supply an email address to the Association or to update the 
address in a manner required by this rule may result in an Owner not receiving 
Association emails. The Association has no duty to request an updated email address 
from an Owner, in response to returned email or otherwise. The Association may 
require Owners to sign up for a group email, email list serve, or other such email 
subscription service in order to receive Association emails. An Owner is required to 
notify the Association when email addresses change. Such notice must be in writing 
and delivered to the Association’s managing agent by fax, mail, or email. The notice 
must be for the sole purpose of requesting an update to the Owner’s email address. 
For example, merely sending an email from a new email address, or including an 
email address in a communication sent for any other purpose other than providing 
notice of a new email address, does not constitute a request to change or add the 
Owner’s email in the records of the Association.

notice from the Board. 

L. MISCELLANEOUS 

L-1. Mailing Address. An Owner who receives mail at any address other than the address of his Unit 
must maintain with the Association his current mailing address. Notifications of change of name 
or change of address should be clearly marked as such. All notices required to be sent to Owners 
by the Documents may be sent to an Owner's most recent address as shown on the records of the 
Association. If an Owner fails to provide a forwarding address, the address of that Owner's Unit is 
deemed effective for purposes of delivery. 

L-2. Revision. These Rules are subject to being revised, replaced, or supplemented, and Owners and 
Residents are urged to contact the Association to verify the rules currently in effect on any 
matter of interest. These Rules will remain effective until ten (10) days after an Owner of each 
Unit has been given a notice of the amendment or revocation of these Rules. 

L-3. Other Rights. These Rules are in addition to and in no way whatsoever detract from the rights of 
the Association under the other Documents and the laws of the State of Texas.

be considered and action(s) toward resolution will be at the Board's discretion. 

1. The Chandler Creek HOA swimming pool is a SWIM AT YOUR OWN RISK pool.  No lifeguards are on duty.  Children 
under the age of 16 must be accompanied by a Chandler Creek HOA resident 18 years of age or older.  This rule is 
strictly enforced. 

2. Use of any facility and/or equipment in the pool area is at your discretion. Please use caution. 

3. All Chandler Creek HOA residents are required to show their pool access pass device and a valid State of Texas ID if 
requested by a Pool Monitor.  Failure to comply may result in you being asked to leave the pool area. 

4. The access gates can only be opened with your assigned pool access device.  Gates are to remain closed/locked at all 
times.  The Pool Monitors have been instructed not to open the gate for anyone without a pool access device.  Anyone 
without a pool access device will be asked to retrieve theirs before they will be allowed to enter the pool area.  Under 
no circumstances should the gate(s) be propped open.  There is a $20 replacement fee for lost/defective pool access 
devices. 

5. One household may host up to four (4) pool guests.  All pool guests must be accompanied by a Chandler Creek HOA 
resident who remains at the pool during the guest’s visit. 

6. Chandler Creek homeowners have the authority to always enforce the current pool rules.  Conduct by any person 
deemed to be dangerous, unreasonable, or offensive (including “horseplay”) is not allowed and should be reported to 
the Pool Monitor.  Any individual disciplined repeatedly, or for serious infractions, may lose all pool privileges for the 
rest of the season. 

7. The kiddy pool is limited to children 5 years of age and younger.  Exceptions may be made for older children with injuries 
which would prevent them from safely entering the main pool.  Each child in the kiddy pool must have an adult 
supervisor;

La Ventana Ranch Owners Association
Pool Rules

October 1, 2023

● The LaVentana swimming pools are SWIM AT YOUR OWN RISK pools.

● The swimming pools are for the use of the ROA Members and their invited guests only.

● Pool hours are from 6 am - 10 pm. Maximum guests per household is 12.

● Pools may not be used along with a clubhouse reservation or rental. Pools remain open to residents
at all times

● Leave gates closed. DO NOT prop them open.

● Noise must be kept to a minimum and any music turned off by 9:00 pm.

● Pool furniture cannot be removed from the pool area.

● NO DIVING allowed anywhere in the pool area. No jumping off ledge between the pools.

• 

I 

(f) No oil drilling, oil development operation, oil refining, quarrying or 
mining operations of any kind shall be permitted on the surface of the Property. No oil 
wells, tanks, tunnels, mineral excavations or shafts shall be permitted upon or in any part 
of the Property. No derrick or other structure designed for use in quarrying or boring for 
oil, natural gas or other minerals shall be erected, maintained or permitted on the 
Property. 

(g) No animals, livestock, fowl or poultry of any kind shall be raised, bred or 
kept on the Property, except that dogs, cats or other household pets may be kept for the 
purpose of providing companionship for the private family. Animals are notto be raised, 
bred or kept for commercial purposes or for food. It is the purpose of these provisions to 
restrict the use of the Property so that no person shall quarter on any part of the Property 
cows, horses, bees, pigeons, hogs, sheep, goats, guinea fowls, ducks, chickens, turkeys, 
skunks or any other animals that may interfere with the quietude, health or safety of the 
community. No more than three pets will be permitted on each Lot. Pets must be 
restrained or confined to the rear of the Owner's Lot inside a fenced area or Vlithin the 
house. It is the pet owner's responsibility to keep the Lot clean and free of pet debris. All 
animals must be properly tagged for identification and vaccinated against rabies. 

(h) No Lot or other area on the Property shall be used as a dumping ground 
for rubbish or a site for the accumulation of unsightly materials of any kind, including, 
but not limited to, broken or rusty equipment, disassembled or inoperative cars and 
discarded appliances and furniture. Trash, garbage or other waste shall not be kept 
except in sanitary containers. All equipment for the storage or other disposal of such 
material shall be kept in clean and sanitary condition. All containers and other facilities

The following restrictions apply to signs advertising a political candidate or ballot item for an 
election, as described in Chapter 202: 

a. The signs may be displayed only during the period beginning 90 days before the date of the election to 
which the sign relates and ending 10 days after that election date. 

b. Only one sign for each candidate or ballot item may be displayed at each residence, and no sign may 
be larger than four feet by six feet. 

c. Each sign must be ground-mounted, and no sign may (i) contains roofing material, siding, paving 
materials, flora, one or more balloons or lights, or any other similar building, landscaping, or nonstandard 
decorative component, (ii) be attached in any way to plant material, a traffic control device, a light, a 
trailer, a vehicle, or any other existing structure or object, (iii) include the painting of architectural 
surfaces, (iv) threaten the public health or safety, (v) violate a law, (vi) contain language, graphics, or 
any display that would be offensive to the ordinary person, or (vii) be accompanied by music or other 
sounds, by streamers, or otherwise be distracting to motorists. 

d. The Association may remove a sign displayed in violation of these standards. 

12. Lights: states, " ... No holiday or occasion lighting or decorations shall be installed earlier than 
thirty (30) days prior to occasion and must be removed no later than twenty (20) days after the event. 

13. Disposal of Trash: states, "All rubbish, trash, garbage or other waste shall be kept in sanitary 
containers and out of sight of the Common Area and any street or adjacent Lot, except on days designated 
. .. for pick-up of such garbage." 

14. Animals and Livestock: states, "No more than three (3) pets shall be kept on a Lot. All pets must be 
properly tagged for identification ... No pet may be chained or leashed outside an enclosure unless being 
walked on a leash.

documents.content:
ChimneyHill Residents
IMPORTANT REMINDER REGARDING PETS
In accordance with the ChimneyHill Community Deed Restrictions, all pets must be controlled so as not to imperil the safety of others or create a nuisance, a disturbance or damage to any property with the community.  All pets must be on a leash and always controlled by the owner (NOT STAKED) while outdoors.
It is the responsibility of the pet owner to pick up and properly dispose of ALL animal waste while outdoors with their pets.  Individual Homeowner lots are not approved pet walking areas and should be avoided for animal defecation.   Approved pet walking areas are the Hiking Trail and the area north of Wimbledon Drive.   
Please be courteous to your neighbors and keep our community safe and clean by being RESPONSIBLE for your pets.

K-3. Indoors/Outdoors. A permitted pet must be maintained inside the Unit, and may not be kept on 
a porch, balcony, or deck. No pet is allowed on common elements unless carried or leashed. No 
pet may be leashed to a stationary object on the common elements. 

K-4. Disturbance. Pets must be kept in a manner that does not disturb another Resident's rest or 
peaceful enjoyment of his Unit or the common elements. No pet may be permitted to bark, 
howl, whine, screech, or make other loud noises for extended or repeated periods of time. 

K-5. Damage. Each resident is responsible for any property damage, injury, or disturbance his pet 
may cause or inflict. A Resident who keeps a pet on the Property is deemed to indemnify and 
agrees to hold harmless the Board, the Association, and other Owners and Residents, from any 
loss, claim, or liability of any kind or character whatever resulting from any action of his pet or 
arising by reason of keeping or maintaining the pet on the Property. 

K-6. Pooper Scooper. No Resident may permit his pet to relieve itself on the Property, except in 
areas designated by the Board for this purpose. Each resident is responsible for the removal of 
his pet's wastes from the common elements. The Board may levy a fine against a unit and its

82.102(a) of the Texas Uniform Condominium Act; and 

 
WHEREAS the Association has voted to amend the Initial Rules and Regulations attached to the Community 
Manual (the “Rules”) as follows: 

 
1. Rule C-3 is ADDED to the Rules (“Monthly Rental Fee”) to read in its entirety as follows: 

 

“C-3.   Monthly Rental Fee.  Owners of units being leased shall pay to the Association a fee in 
the amount of $75 per month per leased unit (e.g. if an owner owns two units and leases 
one unit, the Monthly Rental Fee is $75. If the same owner leases two units, the Monthly 
Rental Fee is $150). Monthly Rental Fees are due on the 15th day of each calendar 
month.” 

 
2. Rule J-2 (“Permitted Pets”) is AMENDED and RESTATED to read in its entirety as follows: 

 

“Permitted Pets. Subject to these Rules, a resident may keep in his unit customary domesticated 
house pets, such as domesticated dogs, cats, caged birds, and aquarium fish, provided there are not 
more than two cats, or two dogs, or one cat and one dog.” 

 
3. Rule J-3 (“Prohibited Animals”) is AMENDED and RESTATED to read in its entirety as follows: 

 

“Prohibited Animals. No resident may keep a dangerous or exotic animal, trained attack dog, or 
any other animal deemed by the Board to be a potential threat to the well-being of people or other 
animals. No animal or house pet may be kept, bred, or maintained for any commercial purpose.

Document reference. Reference is hereby made to the Declaration of Condominium Regime of Macmora Cottages, 
a Condominium, filed as Document No. 2005173033 in the Official Public Records of Travis County, Texas 
(together with all amendments and supplements thereto, the “Declaration”). 

Reference is further made to the “Bylaws of Macmora Cottages HOA, Inc.”, attached as Exhibit “B” to the 
Declaration (together with all amendments and supplements thereto, the “Bylaws”).

3.21.2021   
  
  
  

To Enclave   at   Cooper   Lane   HOA   Board   (3)   
PS   Property   Management   (Rickey   Walker)   

  
Cc Laura   Weldon-   Resident   7404   Rook   St   
  

Subject Visitor\Guest   Parking   spots   in   Community   
  
  

Dear   Alan,   Julie   and   Bobby,     
  

First   off,   I   am   sorry   I   am   even   having   to   waste   my   time   and   yours   in   dealing   with   an   issue   such   
as   this,   but   when   something   is   being   resolved   by   our   property   manager   (Rickey),   adequately,   
but   then   I   am   told   via   email   on   3.17.2021   that   he   has   been   advised   by   the   HOA   board   to   “   stop   
all   action   being   taken   and   ignore   the   problem”.    I   now   have   to   take   matters   into   my   own   hands.   
I   don't   even   know   who   the   3   of   you   are,   other   than   via   a   zoom   meeting   once   a   year,   which   is   
fine,   so   please   do   not   take   this   personally   in   any   way.    I   have   lived   here   since   day   1,   follow   the   
rules,   don't   cause   any   issues   and   pay   my   bills-   on   time.    However,   following   rules   and   being   
fair\consistent   are   very   important   to   me.     
  

Based   on   my   above   listed   address,   you   will   know   that   I   have   very   little   visitor\guest   parking   
options   at   this   end   of   the   neighborhood-   which   is   fine-   that   is   my   problem-   I   bought   my   house   
where   I   bought   my   house.    But,   when   you   are   told   the   unassigned\unmarked   curb   spots   are   “for   
visitors   and   guests   and   on   a   first   come\first   served   basis”,   one   should   have   no   issue.    The   
problem   is   that   we   have   two   residents,   using   these   spots   for   storage   of   vehicles   that   never   
move.

1-7. Visitor Spaces. The use of unassigned and visitor parking spaces, if any, must be rotated, may 
not be used for storage of vehicles, and may not be used consistently by the same driver or 
vehicle. The Board may designate some of the unassigned off-street parking spaces, if any, as 
"visitor spaces" for use, exclusively, by guests of Residents. 

1-8. Violations. A vehicle in violation of these Rules may be stickered, wheel-locked, towed, or 
otherwise removed from the Property by the Board, at the expense of the vehicle's Owner. The 
Association expressly disclaims any liability for damage to vehicles on which the Association 
exercises these remedies for Rules violations.

documents.content:
II. INITIAL RULES & REGULATIONS 

These Initial Rules & Regulations are established by MILESTONE COMMUNITY BUILDERS, LLC, a 
Texas limited liability company, for the benefit of the Cooper Lane Condominium Community, Inc., a 
Texas non-profit corporation (the "Association"). These Community Rules are the "Rules" defined in 
Article 1 of the Declaration of Condominium Regime for Cooper Lane Condominiums, recorded as 
Document Number 2015178238 in the Official Public Records of Travis County, Texas, as it may be 
amended (the "Declaration"). 

These Rules are in addition to the provisions of the Declaration and Bylaws. By owning or 
occupying a Unit, each Owner and Resident agrees to abide by these Rules and to comply with the 
obligations of Owners and Residents under the Declaration and Bylaws of the Association. 

Words and phrases defined in the Declaration have the same meaning when used in these 
Rules. In the event of a conflict between Documents, the hierarchy of authority is as follows: 
Declaration (highest), Bylaws, and these Rules (lowest). The Association's board of directors is 
empowered to interpret, enforce, amend, and repeal these Rules. 

A. COMPLIANCE 

A-1. Compliance. Each Owner will comply with the provisions of these Rules, the other Documents, 
and policies adopted by the Board to supplement these Rules, as any of these may be revised 
from time to time. Each Owner, additionally, is responsible for compliance with the Documents 
by the Residents of his Unit, and his or their respective relatives, invitees, tenants, agents, 
employees, or contractors. If a Rule requires or prohibits conduct by an "Owner" or "Resident," 
each of those terms are deemed to include the other, and applies to all persons for whom an 
Owner or Resident is responsible. Any question regarding these rules should be referred to the 
Association The Association has the right to enforce these Rules against any person on the 
Property. 

DRAFTER'S DICTUM

Words and phrases defined in the Declaration have the same meaning when used in these 
Rules. In the event of a conflict between Documents, the hierarchy of authority is as follows: 
Declaration (highest), Bylaws, and these Rules (lowest). The Association's board of directors is 
empowered to interpret, enforce, amend, and repeal these Rules. 
 

A. COMPLIANCE 
 
A-1.  Compliance. Each Owner will comply with the provisions of these Rules, the other Documents, 

and policies adopted by the Board to supplement these Rules, as any of these may be revised 
from time to time. Each Owner, additionally, is responsible for compliance with the Documents

each of those terms are deemed to include the other, and applies to all persons for whom an

EXHIBIT “A” 
 

AMENDED AND RESTATED RULES & REGULATIONS 
 
 

These Community Rules are the “Rules” defined in Article 1 of the Declaration of 
Condominium Regime for Cooper Lane Condominiums, recorded as Document Number 
2015178238 in the Official Public Records of Travis County, Texas, as it may be amended (the 
"Declaration"). 
 

These Rules are in addition to the provisions of the Declaration and Bylaws. By owning or 
occupying a Unit, each Owner and Resident agrees to abide by these Rules and to comply 
with the obligations of Owners and Residents under the Declaration and Bylaws of the 
Association. 
 

Words and phrases defined in the Declaration have the same meaning when used in these 
Rules. In the event of a conflict between Documents, the hierarchy of authority is as follows: 
Declaration (highest), Bylaws, and these Rules (lowest). The Association's board of directors is 
empowered to interpret, enforce, amend, and repeal these Rules. 
 

A. COMPLIANCE 
 
A-1.  Compliance. Each Owner will comply with the provisions of these Rules, the other Documents, 

and policies adopted by the Board to supplement these Rules, as any of these may be revised 
from time to time. Each Owner, additionally, is responsible for compliance with the Documents 
by the Residents of his Unit, and his or their respective relatives, invitees, tenants, agents, 
employees, or contractors. If a Rule requires or prohibits conduct by an "Owner" or "Resident," 
each of those terms are deemed to include the other, and applies to all persons for whom an 
Owner or Resident is responsible. Any question regarding these rules should be referred to the 
Association. The Association has the right to enforce these Rules against any person on the 
Property. 

 

 
 
 
A-2.  Additional Rules. Each Resident must comply with any rules and signs posted from time to time 

on the Property by the Association. Each Resident must comply with notices communicated by

provisions of this document or its enforcement, or may create rights or duties not anticipated by this

on the Property by the Association. Each Resident must comply with notices communicated by 
the Association, from time to time, which may include seasonal or temporary rules, or notice of 
a change affecting use of the Property. Posted and temporary rules are incorporated in these 
Rules by reference. 

A-3. Variance. Circumstances may warrant a variance of these Rules. To obtain a variance an Owner 
must make written application to the Board. The Board's approval of a variance must be in 
writing, and may be conditioned. 

A-4. Limits. It is understood that individuals may have different interpretations of and tolerances for 
these Rules. On lifestyle-related rules, such as the "Community Etiquette" rules below, the 
Association may refrain from acting on a perceived violation unless the Board determines the

the Association if the Owner desires to receive email communications from the 
Association. Failure to supply an email address to the Association or to update the 
address in a manner required by this rule may result in an Owner not receiving 
Association emails. The Association has no duty to request an updated email address 
from an Owner, in response to returned email or otherwise. The Association may 
require Owners to sign up for a group email, email list serve, or other such email 
subscription service in order to receive Association emails. An Owner is required to 
notify the Association when email addresses change. Such notice must be in writing 
and delivered to the Association’s managing agent by fax, mail, or email. The notice 
must be for the sole purpose of requesting an update to the Owner’s email address. 
For example, merely sending an email from a new email address, or including an 
email address in a communication sent for any other purpose other than providing 
notice of a new email address, does not constitute a request to change or add the 
Owner’s email in the records of the Association.

documents.content:
purpose. 

 
I-4.  Nuisances. Each vehicle must be muffled and must be maintained and operated to minimize 

noise, odor, and oil emissions. The use of car horns on the Property is discouraged. No 
vehicle may be kept on the Property if the Board deems it to be unsightly, inoperable, 
inappropriate, or otherwise violative of these Rules. 

 
I-5.  Private Fire Lanes/Obstructions. All drives in the Property are private fire lanes and utility 

easements on which parking of vehicles is prohibited at all times. No vehicle may be parked 
in a manner that impedes or prevents ready access to the Property, driveways, or parking 
spaces. No vehicle may obstruct the flow of traffic, constitute a nuisance, or otherwise create 
a safety hazard. No vehicle may be parked, even temporarily, in spaces reserved for others, in 
fire lanes, or in any area designated as "No Parking." 

 
I-6.  Garages. Because of the shortage of visitor parking within the Property, it is imperative that 

each Resident use their garage or driveway for the parking of vehicles. A Resident with a car 
must use his garage or driveway for routine parking. No garage may be enclosed or used for 
any purpose that prevents the parking of the maximum number of vehicles for which it was 
constructed. Vehicles may not extend into street if parked in the driveway. 

 
I-7.  Visitor Spaces. The use of unassigned and visitor parking spaces, if any, must be rotated, may 

not be used for storage of vehicles, and may not be used consistently by the same driver or 
vehicle. The Board may designate some of the unassigned off-street parking spaces, if any, as 
"visitor spaces" for use, exclusively, by guests of Residents. 

 
I-8.  Violations. A vehicle in violation of these Rules may be stickered, wheel-locked, towed, or 

otherwise removed from the Property by the Board, at the expense of the vehicle's Owner. 
The Association expressly disclaims any liability for damage to vehicles on which the

Cooper Lane Condominium Community, Inc. 

C/o PS Property Management Co., Inc. 
P.O. Box 7079 Round Rock, TX 78660 

Phone: (512) 251-6122 
Fax: (512) 251-3470 

Email: info@psprop.net 
9/28/18 
 
Dear Cooper Lane Condo Owners, 
 
We have noticed some owners doing exterior improvement projects including, landscaping, xeriscaping, 
patios, etc.  As a reminder all project must be submitted to the Board for the Board’s review and 
decision (approved or denied). Below are some rules from the documents regarding the architectural 
request (requesting to make changes to any exterior portions of the community to include the unit and 
landscaping) process. These can all be found in Article 10 Architectural Control and Covenants of the 
Declaration. 
 
1. You must obtain written approval from the Board prior to starting any construction, 
improvements, additions, etc. This includes yards as well. (10.7 of Declaration) 
2. You must submit an application along with plans and specification (nature, kind, shape, color, 
size, materials, and locations) of the work to be performed. (10.9 of Declaration) 
3. If the application is for work that requires a building permit from a municipality or other 
regulatory authority, the Owner must obtain such permit and provide a copy to the Architectural 
Reviewer in conjunction with the application. (10.9 of Declaration) 
4. The Board has up to 60 days to review and answer the request. If the Board does not respond to 
the request in 60 days, the request is deemed denied. (10.8 of Declaration) 
5. The approval must be in writing. Verbal approval or deemed/implied/presumed approval is not 
allowed. (10.8 of Declaration) 
6. If work is not started by the commencement date on the request, or 90 days if no 
commencement date is stated on the request, the approval will automatically terminate, and a new 
request must be submitted for review. (10.8 of Declaration)

c/o PS Property Management Co., Inc. PO Box 7079 Round Rock, Texas 78683




December 11, 2024 Spicewood Point Owners,
Recently, the repair/replacement of patio fences was identified as the responsibility of the unit owner. Estimated cost is between $1500.00 to $2600.00 per unit and there are 26units that have patio fencing.
There have been some questions on having the HOA continue past practice of paying for patio fence repair/replacement. In order for the HOA to pay for patio fencing, a special assessment would be necessary (this expense is not budgeted and would be a significant and unwise drain on reserve funds). A special assessment requires 2/3 of the owners to approve. Based on estimates obtained, the cost of replacing patio fences for the 26 units would be approximately $39,000 to $67,000. This would equate to approximately $1000.00 to $1289.00 per unit (53 units).
Assessments are based on square feet per unit, so exact amounts per unit would vary.
We (the HOA board members) are asking each owner to vote on whether a special assessment should be imposed for patio fence replacement. If passed, then payment in full would be due within 30 days of the special assessment passing. If it fails to pass, then the HOA will not pay for patio fence repair/replacement.
You will be notified via email and regular mail on the voting process. Thank you for your attention to thismatter.
HOA Board
Cindy Williams, Stephen Phister, Judith Kaplan

c/o PS Property Management Co., Inc. PO Box 7079; Round Rock, Texas 78683

 PO Box 7079 Round Rock, Texas 78683 

December 11, 2024 

Spicewood Point Owners, 

Recently, the repair/replacement of patio fences was identified as the responsibility of 
the unit owner. Estimated cost is between $1500.00 to $2600.00 per unit and there 
are 26 units that have patio fencing. 

There have been some questions on having the HOA continue past practice of 
paying for patio fence repair/replacement. In order for the HOA to pay for patio 
fencing, a special assessment would be necessary (this expense is not budgeted and 
would be a significant and unwise drain on reserve funds). A special assessment 
requires 2/3 of the owners to approve. Based on estimates obtained, the cost of 
replacing patio fences for the 26 units would be approximately $39,000 to $67,600. 
This would equate to approximately $736.00 to $1276.00 per unit (53 units). 
Assessments are based on square feet per unit, so exact amounts per unit would vary. 

We (the HOA board members) are asking each owner to vote on whether a special 
assessment should be imposed for patio fence replacement. If passed, then payment 
in full would be due within 30 days of the special assessment passing. If it fails to 
pass, then the HOA will not pay for patio fence repair/replacement. 

You will be notified via email and regular mail on the voting process. Thank 

you for your attention to this matter. 

HOA Board 

Cindy Williams, Stephen Phister, Judith Kaplan

SPICEWOOD POINT HOMEOWNERS ASSOCIATION 
RULES AND REGULATIONS 

 
 
 
1. LIVING UNIT EXTERIORS 
 

1} Unit entry areas 1   front doors, and windows visible from common areas 
shall be reasonably clean and neat, and in good  repair. 

 
2) No structural or otherwise 11 affixed 1 additions or changes (such as 

awnings, storm doors, TV antennas, etc.) shall be allowed except as 
approved by    the Board of Directors prior to installation. 

 
3) Balconies and patios visible from common areas or from the street 

shall be reasonably clean and uncluttered; railings and fences shall 
not be used to hang towels, rugs, etc. 

 
4) By City Ordinance, no grills are allowed on balconies or patios, 

beneath an overhang, or within five feet of the building. Violation 
of this ordinance can result in a fine of $500.00. 

 
'S) Window coverings visible from common areas or street shall be  of a 

neutral or light color. 
 

6) Signs advertising a unit 1 s availability for sale, rent or lease 
shall be displayed in only one window of the unit, and with prior 
consent of the Board or Management Company. Such signs shall be no 
larger than two feet by two feet. 

 
 
2. COMMON AREAS FIXTURES AND FURNISHINGS 

 
1) No one other than authorized personnel shall adjust, repair or 

otherwise physically alter equipment such as sprinklers, pool 
supplies and controls, lights, etc. Homeowners shall notify 
maintenance personnel or the Management Company when problems occur. 

 
2) Pool furniture shall not be removed from the pool area, or used for 

any purpose except that for which it is designed. 
 

3) Plants shall not be removed, altered, or planted without prior 
consent of the Board. 

 
4) Personal notices (Lost & Found, For Sale, etc.) posted on the 

mailbox kiosk shall be no larger than 4n X 5n inches and shall be 
displayed for no longer than two weeks. Homeowners and residents 
only shall be allowed to post notices.

7. PETS 
 

1) Only such animals as are generally considered household pets shall 
be kept on the premises. No more than two pets per unit shall be 
allowed except as permitted by prior variance from the Board of 
Directors. 

 
2) Pets shall be kept indoors, in fenced-in back yards, or on 

balconies or patios. They shall be allowed in common areas ONLY 
WHEN DIRECTLY SUPERVISED BY THEIR OWNERS. 

 
3) Dogs and cats shall ALWAYS be on leashes when in common areas. 

 
4) Pet owners shall be responsible for immediate removal and clean-up 

of their pets 1 waste in common areas and on balconies and patios 
abutting common areas. 

 
5) Pets shall not be allowed in the pool area or clubhouse. 

(This does not apply to animals assisting handicapped  individuals.) 
 

6) Homeowners shall be responsible for any personal injury or property 
damage caused by   pets owned or under the care of the persons 
residing in their units, whether such persons be homeowners 
themselves or their tenants. 

 
REMARKS 

 
All owners and residents have the right to expect that these Rules and 
Regulations be enforced for their own sense of well-being and that of 
their neighbors.

EMERGENCY PROCEDURES 

 
1. FIRE  Leave involved area immediately and call 911 from a safe 
location. Alert other residents if possible. 
 
2. UTILITIES HAZARDS (Gas, Water, Electricity) Contact Pioneer Real 
Estate immediately (512-447-4496) 
 
3. SUSPICIOUS PERSON ON OR NEAR PREMISES Call police at 512-480-
5011 (or call 911 if immediate response is judged necessary). Inform 
Pioneer Real Estate of the situation as soon as possible 
info@pioneeraustin.com 
 
4. DANGEROUS WEATHER  Take precautions as directed by local 
authorities by means of the media; alert other residents if possible. 
During winter months be alert for media advisories and signs at 
mailboxes regarding freeze warnings, take precautions for water pipes 
as directed. 
 
5. STRAY ANIMALS  Call City of Austin 311 (or, if an animal seems 
to present an immediate threat, 911).

not be used to hang towels, rugs, etc. 

 
4) By City Ordinance, no grills are allowed on balconies or patios, 

beneath an overhang, or within five feet of the building. Violation 
of this ordinance can result in a fine of $500.00. 

 
'S) Window coverings visible from common areas or street shall be  of a 

neutral or light color. 
 

6) Signs advertising a unit 1 s availability for sale, rent or lease 
shall be displayed in only one window of the unit, and with prior 
consent of the Board or Management Company. Such signs shall be no 
larger than two feet by two feet. 

 
 
2. COMMON AREAS FIXTURES AND FURNISHINGS 

 
1) No one other than authorized personnel shall adjust, repair or 

otherwise physically alter equipment such as sprinklers, pool 
supplies and controls, lights, etc. Homeowners shall notify 
maintenance personnel or the Management Company when problems occur. 

 
2) Pool furniture shall not be removed from the pool area, or used for 

any purpose except that for which it is designed. 
 

3) Plants shall not be removed, altered, or planted without prior 
consent of the Board. 

 
4) Personal notices (Lost & Found, For Sale, etc.) posted on the 

mailbox kiosk shall be no larger than 4n X 5n inches and shall be 
displayed for no longer than two weeks. Homeowners and residents 
only shall be allowed to post notices. 



Page 2  

 
 

3, POOL AND HOT TUB

1. The Chandler Creek HOA swimming pool is a SWIM AT YOUR OWN RISK pool.  No lifeguards are on duty.  Children 
under the age of 16 must be accompanied by a Chandler Creek HOA resident 18 years of age or older.  This rule is 
strictly enforced. 

2. Use of any facility and/or equipment in the pool area is at your discretion. Please use caution. 

3. All Chandler Creek HOA residents are required to show their pool access pass device and a valid State of Texas ID if 
requested by a Pool Monitor.  Failure to comply may result in you being asked to leave the pool area. 

4. The access gates can only be opened with your assigned pool access device.  Gates are to remain closed/locked at all 
times.  The Pool Monitors have been instructed not to open the gate for anyone without a pool access device.  Anyone 
without a pool access device will be asked to retrieve theirs before they will be allowed to enter the pool area.  Under 
no circumstances should the gate(s) be propped open.  There is a $20 replacement fee for lost/defective pool access 
devices. 

5. One household may host up to four (4) pool guests.  All pool guests must be accompanied by a Chandler Creek HOA 
resident who remains at the pool during the guest’s visit. 

6. Chandler Creek homeowners have the authority to always enforce the current pool rules.  Conduct by any person 
deemed to be dangerous, unreasonable, or offensive (including “horseplay”) is not allowed and should be reported to 
the Pool Monitor.  Any individual disciplined repeatedly, or for serious infractions, may lose all pool privileges for the 
rest of the season. 

7. The kiddy pool is limited to children 5 years of age and younger.  Exceptions may be made for older children with injuries 
which would prevent them from safely entering the main pool.  Each child in the kiddy pool must have an adult 
supervisor;

(d) Trash cans indoors and outdoors are to be emptied and trash placed in the trash bins located in parking lot.
(e) Restrooms trash cans emptied and countertops wiped down.
(f) All furniture must be returned to its original position.
(g) All greenery, flowers, decorations and other items brought in must be removed.
(h) Pavilion, if used, should be swept, all trash cans emptied and furniture put back to its original place.
(i) All lights, appliances and fans must be turned off.
Failure to strictly comply with the cleaning requirements will result in forfeit of security deposit.

Damages: The ROA Member will be held responsible for any damage caused by the member and or their
guests. The breach or violation of any condition set forth herein may result in the loss of the security deposit,
the imposition of liability on the ROA Member, and possible denial of future rentals of the Clubhouse.

Right of Refusal: The Association reserves the right to refuse to rent the facilities for any purpose it deems to
be detrimental to or not in the best interests of its members. It further reserves the right to refuse to rent the
facilities on any dates and at any time it deems inappropriate or inconvenient to residents of La Ventana.

La Ventana Clubhouse Rental Rules, Regulations and Pool Rules 3



La Ventana Ranch Owners Association
Pool Rules

October 1, 2023

● The LaVentana swimming pools are SWIM AT YOUR OWN RISK pools.

● The swimming pools are for the use of the ROA Members and their invited guests only.

● Pool hours are from 6 am - 10 pm. Maximum guests per household is 12.

● Pools may not be used along with a clubhouse reservation or rental. Pools remain open to residents
at all times

● Leave gates closed. DO NOT prop them open.

● Noise must be kept to a minimum and any music turned off by 9:00 pm.

● Pool furniture cannot be removed from the pool area.

● NO DIVING allowed anywhere in the pool area. No jumping off ledge between the pools.

courtyard. 

22. Access to the multi-purpose room is by advance reservation only. 

Miscellaneous: 

Restrooms:  The restroom fixtures are sanitized and cleaned by a private janitorial service.  The designated maintenance 
person/company is responsible for cleaning mirrors, counters, stocking hand towels, soap, emptying trashed and cleaning 
the floors and toilets.  Please be mindful of other HOA members by cleaning up after yourself when using the restrooms.  If 
the restroom should require attention, please notify the Pool Monitor on duty or call the current HOA management 
company. 

Penalties for Violation of Pool Rules: 

Depending on upon severity of offense, action taken by the HOA for violation of HOA pool rues may include one or more of 
the following: 

• 1st offense – A written warning is issued (notification of registered homeowner, parent, or guardian, when 
applicable) 

• 2nd offense – A second written warning is issued. 

• 3rd offense – Pool privileges are revoked, and pool card deactivated. 

• Criminal and civil complaints are filed when applicable: 
1. Notification of Sheriff’s Office 
2. Prosecution and/or other legal remedies

ASSUMPTION OF RISK AND WAIVER OF NOTICE: Grantee acknowledges, on behalf of Grantee, that this is a swim-at-your-own-risk facility at all 
times, whether or not a lifeguard may be on duty, and assumes all risk associated with use of swimming facility with knowledge that risks include 
possible injury or death due to drowning, slip and fall, or other peril.  Please see your Association’s pool rules for additional information.  Grantee 
hereby acknowledges Grantee has received, has read, and fully understands the pool rules, guidelines, and other restrictions and hereby accepts 
them and agrees to abide by them.  Grantee hereby acknowledges that failure to abide by the pool rules and guidelines may result in suspension of 
pool privileges.  Grantee hereby accepts all responsibility for any family member, guest or invitees using the pool.  If Association uses pool access 
devices, Grantee hereby waives statutory requirement of notice prior to deactivation of any pool access device for nonpayment of Association 
dues or other fees and accepts this notice in lieu of certified notice.  Grantee understands and agrees that any pool device may be deactivated if 
Association dues or other fees are not in good standing.  Grantee hereby acknowledges that the pool access device(s) are under no warranty and 
have been advised that device(s) are not waterproof.  DO NOT WET DEVICE(S). 

SEVERABILITY: If any provision of this Agreement is held to be partially or completely contrary to law, and/or unenforceable, this Agreement shall 
be deemed to be amended to partially or completely modify such provision, or portion thereof, to the extent necessary to make it enforceable; or,

documents.content:
fibers can clog pool filters and create the need for expensive repairs. 

16. Children who are not toilet-trained are not allowed in either the main pool or the kiddy pool without a “swim” diaper 
and must always be accompanied by an adult within arm’s length.  Children wearing regular diapers are not allowed in 
either the main pool or the kiddy pool.  “Swim” diapers must always be used.  If your child or anyone else in your party 
is found to be responsible for a closure due to fecal matter, all costs to clean and reopen the pool may be assigned to 
your household via your HOA account.  If a fecal accident occurs: All swimmers must exit the pool immediately and the 
pool will be closed for the minimum time frame as allowed by law from the time the pool has been chemically treated.  
Incidents should be immediately reported to the current HOA management company and/or the Pool Monitor on duty. 

17. Persons having currently active diarrhea or who have had active diarrhea within the previous 14 days are not allowed to 
enter the pool water. 

18. No smoking or any other use of tobacco products (Skoal, chewing tobacco, vapor cigarettes, etc.).  The following are not 
permitted in the pool area or surrounding park under any circumstances: alcohol, firearms, or drugs.  Individuals 
engaging in the use of such are subject to loss of privileges for a period to be determined by the HOA Board. Other legal 
actions may be taken in conjunction with the Williamson County Sheriff’s Office. 

19. Swim safely and treat others as you would like to be treated.  Residents are responsible for the behavior of those in their 
household and/or their guests. 

20. In the event of inclement weather, swimmers are to clear the pool during the storm and for at least thirty (30) minutes 
after lightning and/or thunder has ceased. 

21. Any resident may call the current HOA management company to report unsafe behavior or violations of pool rules they 
witness.

(f) No oil drilling, oil development operation, oil refining, quarrying or 
mining operations of any kind shall be permitted on the surface of the Property. No oil 
wells, tanks, tunnels, mineral excavations or shafts shall be permitted upon or in any part 
of the Property. No derrick or other structure designed for use in quarrying or boring for 
oil, natural gas or other minerals shall be erected, maintained or permitted on the 
Property. 

(g) No animals, livestock, fowl or poultry of any kind shall be raised, bred or 
kept on the Property, except that dogs, cats or other household pets may be kept for the 
purpose of providing companionship for the private family. Animals are notto be raised, 
bred or kept for commercial purposes or for food. It is the purpose of these provisions to 
restrict the use of the Property so that no person shall quarter on any part of the Property 
cows, horses, bees, pigeons, hogs, sheep, goats, guinea fowls, ducks, chickens, turkeys, 
skunks or any other animals that may interfere with the quietude, health or safety of the 
community. No more than three pets will be permitted on each Lot. Pets must be 
restrained or confined to the rear of the Owner's Lot inside a fenced area or Vlithin the 
house. It is the pet owner's responsibility to keep the Lot clean and free of pet debris. All 
animals must be properly tagged for identification and vaccinated against rabies. 

(h) No Lot or other area on the Property shall be used as a dumping ground 
for rubbish or a site for the accumulation of unsightly materials of any kind, including, 
but not limited to, broken or rusty equipment, disassembled or inoperative cars and 
discarded appliances and furniture. Trash, garbage or other waste shall not be kept 
except in sanitary containers. All equipment for the storage or other disposal of such 
material shall be kept in clean and sanitary condition. All containers and other facilities

The following restrictions apply to signs advertising a political candidate or ballot item for an 
election, as described in Chapter 202: 

a. The signs may be displayed only during the period beginning 90 days before the date of the election to 
which the sign relates and ending 10 days after that election date. 

b. Only one sign for each candidate or ballot item may be displayed at each residence, and no sign may 
be larger than four feet by six feet. 

c. Each sign must be ground-mounted, and no sign may (i) contains roofing material, siding, paving 
materials, flora, one or more balloons or lights, or any other similar building, landscaping, or nonstandard 
decorative component, (ii) be attached in any way to plant material, a traffic control device, a light, a 
trailer, a vehicle, or any other existing structure or object, (iii) include the painting of architectural 
surfaces, (iv) threaten the public health or safety, (v) violate a law, (vi) contain language, graphics, or 
any display that would be offensive to the ordinary person, or (vii) be accompanied by music or other 
sounds, by streamers, or otherwise be distracting to motorists. 

d. The Association may remove a sign displayed in violation of these standards. 

12. Lights: states, " ... No holiday or occasion lighting or decorations shall be installed earlier than 
thirty (30) days prior to occasion and must be removed no later than twenty (20) days after the event. 

13. Disposal of Trash: states, "All rubbish, trash, garbage or other waste shall be kept in sanitary 
containers and out of sight of the Common Area and any street or adjacent Lot, except on days designated 
. .. for pick-up of such garbage." 

14. Animals and Livestock: states, "No more than three (3) pets shall be kept on a Lot. All pets must be 
properly tagged for identification ... No pet may be chained or leashed outside an enclosure unless being 
walked on a leash.

documents.content:
ChimneyHill Residents
IMPORTANT REMINDER REGARDING PETS
In accordance with the ChimneyHill Community Deed Restrictions, all pets must be controlled so as not to imperil the safety of others or create a nuisance, a disturbance or damage to any property with the community.  All pets must be on a leash and always controlled by the owner (NOT STAKED) while outdoors.
It is the responsibility of the pet owner to pick up and properly dispose of ALL animal waste while outdoors with their pets.  Individual Homeowner lots are not approved pet walking areas and should be avoided for animal defecation.   Approved pet walking areas are the Hiking Trail and the area north of Wimbledon Drive.   
Please be courteous to your neighbors and keep our community safe and clean by being RESPONSIBLE for your pets.

82.102(a) of the Texas Uniform Condominium Act; and 

 
WHEREAS the Association has voted to amend the Initial Rules and Regulations attached to the Community 
Manual (the “Rules”) as follows: 

 
1. Rule C-3 is ADDED to the Rules (“Monthly Rental Fee”) to read in its entirety as follows: 

 

“C-3.   Monthly Rental Fee.  Owners of units being leased shall pay to the Association a fee in 
the amount of $75 per month per leased unit (e.g. if an owner owns two units and leases 
one unit, the Monthly Rental Fee is $75. If the same owner leases two units, the Monthly 
Rental Fee is $150). Monthly Rental Fees are due on the 15th day of each calendar 
month.” 

 
2. Rule J-2 (“Permitted Pets”) is AMENDED and RESTATED to read in its entirety as follows: 

 

“Permitted Pets. Subject to these Rules, a resident may keep in his unit customary domesticated 
house pets, such as domesticated dogs, cats, caged birds, and aquarium fish, provided there are not 
more than two cats, or two dogs, or one cat and one dog.” 

 
3. Rule J-3 (“Prohibited Animals”) is AMENDED and RESTATED to read in its entirety as follows: 

 

“Prohibited Animals. No resident may keep a dangerous or exotic animal, trained attack dog, or 
any other animal deemed by the Board to be a potential threat to the well-being of people or other 
animals. No animal or house pet may be kept, bred, or maintained for any commercial purpose.

Document reference. Reference is hereby made to the Declaration of Condominium Regime of Macmora Cottages, 
a Condominium, filed as Document No. 2005173033 in the Official Public Records of Travis County, Texas 
(together with all amendments and supplements thereto, the “Declaration”). 

Reference is further made to the “Bylaws of Macmora Cottages HOA, Inc.”, attached as Exhibit “B” to the 
Declaration (together with all amendments and supplements thereto, the “Bylaws”).

SPICEWOOD POINT HOMEOWNERS ASSOCIATION 
RULES AND REGULATIONS 

 
 
 
1. LIVING UNIT EXTERIORS 
 

1} Unit entry areas 1   front doors, and windows visible from common areas 
shall be reasonably clean and neat, and in good  repair. 

 
2) No structural or otherwise 11 affixed 1 additions or changes (such as 

awnings, storm doors, TV antennas, etc.) shall be allowed except as 
approved by    the Board of Directors prior to installation. 

 
3) Balconies and patios visible from common areas or from the street 

shall be reasonably clean and uncluttered; railings and fences shall 
not be used to hang towels, rugs, etc. 

 
4) By City Ordinance, no grills are allowed on balconies or patios, 

beneath an overhang, or within five feet of the building. Violation 
of this ordinance can result in a fine of $500.00. 

 
'S) Window coverings visible from common areas or street shall be  of a 

neutral or light color. 
 

6) Signs advertising a unit 1 s availability for sale, rent or lease 
shall be displayed in only one window of the unit, and with prior 
consent of the Board or Management Company. Such signs shall be no 
larger than two feet by two feet. 

 
 
2. COMMON AREAS FIXTURES AND FURNISHINGS 

 
1) No one other than authorized personnel shall adjust, repair or 

otherwise physically alter equipment such as sprinklers, pool 
supplies and controls, lights, etc. Homeowners shall notify 
maintenance personnel or the Management Company when problems occur. 

 
2) Pool furniture shall not be removed from the pool area, or used for 

any purpose except that for which it is designed. 
 

3) Plants shall not be removed, altered, or planted without prior 
consent of the Board. 

 
4) Personal notices (Lost & Found, For Sale, etc.) posted on the 

mailbox kiosk shall be no larger than 4n X 5n inches and shall be 
displayed for no longer than two weeks. Homeowners and residents 
only shall be allowed to post notices.

7) Except for routine repairs (battery charging, tire changing, etc.)

8) Motorcycles shall park only in spaces designed for cars,--never on

9) Boats, campers, large trucks and trailers shall not park on the

VEHICLES IN VIOLATION OF THESE RULES ARE 

SUBJECT TO BEING TOWED AT THE OWNERS EXPENSE 
 
5. TRASH Jilil)  RECYCLING 
 

1) All household trash and garbage shall be deposited INSIDE one of 
the dumpsters on the property. Items too large for dumpsters, as 
well as pollutants and potentially hazardous materials  and  
substances, shall be removed from the property by the resident 
discarding them. 

 
2) Items to be recycled shall be deposited INSIDE receptacles provided 

for that purpose. Garbage or trash of any kind shall not be put in 
-recycling containers. 

 
3) No litter of any kind, especially drink and fast food containers, 

·shall be allowed in any common area, including driveways and 
parking areas, or in any other area visible from a common area or 
the street. 

 
6. NOISE CONTROL 

 
1) Sound from radios and tv's and recorded or live music of any kind 

shall not be audible beyond the walls of the units in which it 
originates--except in special cases in which prior consent has been 
obtained from all neighbors likely to be affected.

Vehicle Condition Requirements. A vehicle must be operable, and must display a 

current license tag or plate, and inspection sticker. An “inoperable” vehicle is one that is 

obviously or actually not capable of being operated as a vehicle. Each vehicle must be 

maintained and operated to minimize noise, odor, and oil emissions. No vehicle may be 

parked in the Common Elements if the Board deems it to be unsightly, inoperable, 

inappropriate, or otherwise in violation of these rules. 

Violations. A vehicle in violation of these Rules may be stickered/ticketed, wheel-locked, 

towed, or otherwise removed from the Property by the Board, at the expense of the 

vehicle's owner. The Association expressly disclaims any liability for damage to vehicles 

on which the Association exercises these remedies for Rules violations. 

C. Enforcement. 

Interpretation. In the event of any dispute regarding the effect or application of this 

policy, the interpretation of the Board of Directors (the “Board”) will be final. 

Nuisance. Every act or omission whereby any provision of this policy is violated, in 

whole or in part, is hereby declared to be a nuisance. 

Self-Help. A vehicle in violation of this policy may be towed, by or at the direction of the 

Association, at the expense of the vehicle’s owner. The Association expressly disclaims 

any liability for damage to vehicles on which the Association exercises these remedies 

for violations of this policy. 

Fines. The Association may impose fines for violation of the provisions of this policy 

pursuant to the provisions and procedures of the Association’s Fine and Enforcement 

Policy, as the same may be amended from time to time.

documents.content:
only. At no time shall an Owner or 

a tenant use a visitor parking space. Guests who occupy a Unit overnight shall 

not use visitor parking spaces. Visitor parking spaces are limited to a maximum 

of four (4) hours in any twenty-four (24) hour period. 

PARKING RULES 

A, Designated Parking. 

Assigned Unit Parking. Each Unit is the subject of a recorded Assignment of Parking 

instrument that identifies the parking space or spaces designated for the exclusive use of 

a Unit (an “Assigned Space”). Owners and their tenants must use the Assigned Space 

designated for the exclusive use of the Unit they own or occupy and the parked vehicle 

must fit within the Assigned Space. Owners and their tenants may not park in any area 

or space other than the appropriate Assigned Space. 

Visitor Parking. The guest parking spaces located within the Regime are designated for 

non-resident, visitor parking only. These guest parking spaces must be shared among 

the community. These spaces may not be used for storage of vehicles and may not be 

used consistently by the same driver or vehicle. At no time shall a resident, tenant, or 

occupant use a visitor parking space. Guests who occupy a Unit overnight shall not use 

visitor parking spaces. Visitor parking spaces are limited to a maximum of four (4) hours 

in any twenty-four (24) hour period, unless otherwise approved in advance, in writing, 

by the Board.

prevents access to driveways or parking spaces. No vehicle may be parked, even 

temporarily, in fire lanes or in any area designated as "No Parking”. Vehicles parked in

so as not to detract from others1       enjoyment of the area.) 

 
5) No glass containers shall be allowed anywhere in the pool/hot tub 

area. 
 

6) Nothing shall be taken or allowed in the pool except items 
specifically designed for pool use, such as floats and swimming 
aids. 

 
7) No  activity  including  11 p l a y 11   shall  be allowed  in  or  around  the 

pool/ hot tub area which is potentially harmful to or disturbing to 
persons or property, DIVING SHALL NEVER BE ALLOWED, 

 
4, VEHICLES 

 
1) Residents shall be allowed no more than two vehicles on the 

property per living unit at any time except as permitted by 
prior variance from the Board of· Directors. 

 
2) Residents shall at no time park in assigned spaces other 

than their own, except by prior mutual agreement between themselves 
and the rightful designees for the spaces. 

 
3) Residents shall inform all visitors, including repair and service 

persons that they are to park ONLY IN UNCOVERED PARKING SPACES, 
Guest parking shall not exceed a 48-hour period. 

 
4) Parking shall at no time be allowed where prohibited by curb 

marking, or in any other place that would restrict residents 1 

access and use of their living units or vehicles.

Dear   Alan,   Julie   and   Bobby,     
  

First   off,   I   am   sorry   I   am   even   having   to   waste   my   time   and   yours   in   dealing   with   an   issue   such   
as   this,   but   when   something   is   being   resolved   by   our   property   manager   (Rickey),   adequately,   
but   then   I   am   told   via   email   on   3.17.2021   that   he   has   been   advised   by   the   HOA   board   to   “   stop   
all   action   being   taken   and   ignore   the   problem”.    I   now   have   to   take   matters   into   my   own   hands.   
I   don't   even   know   who   the   3   of   you   are,   other   than   via   a   zoom   meeting   once   a   year,   which   is   
fine,   so   please   do   not   take   this   personally   in   any   way.    I   have   lived   here   since   day   1,   follow   the   
rules,   don't   cause   any   issues   and   pay   my   bills-   on   time.    However,   following   rules   and   being   
fair\consistent   are   very   important   to   me.     
  

Based   on   my   above   listed   address,   you   will   know   that   I   have   very   little   visitor\guest   parking   
options   at   this   end   of   the   neighborhood-   which   is   fine-   that   is   my   problem-   I   bought   my   house   
where   I   bought   my   house.    But,   when   you   are   told   the   unassigned\unmarked   curb   spots   are   “for   
visitors   and   guests   and   on   a   first   come\first   served   basis”,   one   should   have   no   issue.    The   
problem   is   that   we   have   two   residents,   using   these   spots   for   storage   of   vehicles   that   never   
move.

or their tenants. 

 
REMARKS 

 
All owners and residents have the right to expect that these Rules and 
Regulations be enforced for their own sense of well-being and that of 
their neighbors. They should not hesitate to register complaints when 
warranted. (Lessees and renters shall contact owners of their leased or 
rented units, who in turn shall contact the Management Company or a Board 
member.} 

 
Owners are responsible for keeping tenants informed as to these Rules and 
Regulations, as well as any future additions or changes, and for acting as 
liaison between their tenants and the Board of Directors and Management 
Company on specific questions or problems related to policy. 

 
Owners are responsible for any violations committed by their tenants or 
their tenants 1 guests. Owners are responsible for notifying the management 
company of the names of their renters and for providing a key to the units 
Owners are responsible for any violations committed by their tenants or 
their tenants 1    guests. 



Page 5  

 
EMERGENCY PROCEDURES 

 
1. FIRE  Leave involved area immediately and call 911 from a safe 
location. Alert other residents if possible. 
 
2. UTILITIES HAZARDS (Gas, Water, Electricity) Contact Pioneer Real 
Estate immediately (512-447-4496) 
 
3. SUSPICIOUS PERSON ON OR NEAR PREMISES Call police at 512-480-
5011 (or call 911 if immediate response is judged necessary). Inform 
Pioneer Real Estate of the situation as soon as possible 
info@pioneeraustin.com 
 
4. DANGEROUS WEATHER  Take precautions as directed by local 
authorities by means of the media; alert other residents if possible. 
During winter months be alert for media advisories and signs at 
mailboxes regarding freeze warnings, take precautions for water pipes 
as directed. 
 
5. STRAY ANIMALS  Call City of Austin 311 (or, if an animal seems 
to present an immediate threat, 911).

	2. COMMON AREAS FIXTURES AND FURNISHINGS

may be replaced and stained a matching wood-tone for maintenance 
purposes, without ACC approval 

• Shared fence must good neighbor design 
• Fences that abut trail feature must be good neighbor and no taller than six 

feet (6') 
• Fences that abut trail feature must not have a mounted advertising placard with 

the fence vendor's name 

H. Front Porch Patio Surface 
• May be sealed or stained, tiled, or fitted with stone work, without ACC 

approval 

I. Roofing Materials 

• Asphalt shingles of the same style and design and color as original materials 
are allowed, without ACC approval 

Section 7 - Guidelines for Project Approval 
Allowed exterior modifications listed in this section may only be made after approval has 
been received in writing from the ACC, upon submission of a project to the Architectural 
Control Committee. 

A. Antennas & Cable installations 
• Allowed as far out of public view as possible, and in accordance with 

Section 11.17 of the Declaration, with ACC approval 

B. Pedestrian Sidewalk - (Right of Way) 
• May not be sealed, stained, painted, or colored* 
• May not be lined with edging material of any type 

* Unless the community decides to do so as a whole 

C. Driveway 
• May not be sealed, stained, painted, or colored 
• May not be lined with edging material of any type causing interference 

with mowing 
• May not be expanded 

D. Personal Sidewalk 
• May not be painted. May not be lined with edging material of anytype 
• May be etched and stained, with ACC approval 
• May have stone work applied, with ACC approval 
• Reason: to avoid interference with the lawn maintenance service 

E. Front-Yard Plant & Tree Beds 
• May be fenced, lined with stone, plant material, or bed edging with ACC 

approval

documents.content:
plus (15'+) driveway, with ACC 
approval 

Y. Stone Pathways 

• Stone pathways in which loose gravel, only, is placed over non­
compacted soil are allowed, with ACC approval. These type of pathways 
currently do not contribute to impervious coverage as defined in City of 
Austin definitions of impervious coverage, per Chapter 25-8, of the 
current Watershed Protection Ordinance 

• Pathways which are constructed of impervious material, partially impervious 
material, or are constructed on compacted soil are subject to impervious cover 
limitations for the residence and the community and may only be constructed 
with ACC approval 

Z. Tree Houses 

• Tree houses or club houses located in trees are not allowed 

Section 8 - Fees 
Projects involving changes to the unit to or changes to impervious coverage shall include a fee 
of $35 with the project submission. 

The exterior modifications that include replacements listed in Section 6, above, may be 
accomplished without application or fee. 

Section 9 - Drawing Required 
In order to facilitate project approval, a "drawing to scale" is required, including 
dimensions, with all project submissions that involve impervious coverage. This is to aid 
the ACC in calculating the square area oftheproject. 

Section 10 - Variance 
An Owner may submit a request for a variance from the requirements of these Guidelines with 
an ACC application.
