only. At no time shall an Owner or 

a tenant use a visitor parking space. Guests who occupy a Unit overnight shall 

not use visitor parking spaces. Visitor parking spaces are limited to a maximum 

of four (4) hours in any twenty-four (24) hour period. 

PARKING RULES 

A, Designated Parking. 

Assigned Unit Parking. Each Unit is the subject of a recorded Assignment of Parking 

instrument that identifies the parking space or spaces designated for the exclusive use of 

a Unit (an “Assigned Space”). Owners and their tenants must use the Assigned Space 

designated for the exclusive use of the Unit they own or occupy and the parked vehicle 

must fit within the Assigned Space. Owners and their tenants may not park in any area 

or space other than the appropriate Assigned Space. 

Visitor Parking. The guest parking spaces located within the Regime are designated for 

non-resident, visitor parking only. These guest parking spaces must be shared among 

the community. These spaces may not be used for storage of vehicles and may not be 

used consistently by the same driver or vehicle. At no time shall a resident, tenant, or 

occupant use a visitor parking space. Guests who occupy a Unit overnight shall not use 

visitor parking spaces. Visitor parking spaces are limited to a maximum of four (4) hours 

in any twenty-four (24) hour period, unless otherwise approved in advance, in writing, 

by the Board.

prevents access to driveways or parking spaces. No vehicle may be parked, even 

temporarily, in fire lanes or in any area designated as "No Parking”. Vehicles parked in

3.21.2021   
  
  
  

To Enclave   at   Cooper   Lane   HOA   Board   (3)   
PS   Property   Management   (Rickey   Walker)   

  
Cc Laura   Weldon-   Resident   7404   Rook   St   
  

Subject Visitor\Guest   Parking   spots   in   Community   
  
  

Dear   Alan,   Julie   and   Bobby,     
  

First   off,   I   am   sorry   I   am   even   having   to   waste   my   time   and   yours   in   dealing   with   an   issue   such   
as   this,   but   when   something   is   being   resolved   by   our   property   manager   (Rickey),   adequately,   
but   then   I   am   told   via   email   on   3.17.2021   that   he   has   been   advised   by   the   HOA   board   to   “   stop   
all   action   being   taken   and   ignore   the   problem”.    I   now   have   to   take   matters   into   my   own   hands.   
I   don't   even   know   who   the   3   of   you   are,   other   than   via   a   zoom   meeting   once   a   year,   which   is   
fine,   so   please   do   not   take   this   personally   in   any   way.    I   have   lived   here   since   day   1,   follow   the   
rules,   don't   cause   any   issues   and   pay   my   bills-   on   time.    However,   following   rules   and   being   
fair\consistent   are   very   important   to   me.     
  

Based   on   my   above   listed   address,   you   will   know   that   I   have   very   little   visitor\guest   parking   
options   at   this   end   of   the   neighborhood-   which   is   fine-   that   is   my   problem-   I   bought   my   house   
where   I   bought   my   house.    But,   when   you   are   told   the   unassigned\unmarked   curb   spots   are   “for   
visitors   and   guests   and   on   a   first   come\first   served   basis”,   one   should   have   no   issue.    The   
problem   is   that   we   have   two   residents,   using   these   spots   for   storage   of   vehicles   that   never   
move.

WHEREAS, a duly called meeting of the Board of Directors (the "Board") of the Enclave@ Forest Creek 
Homeowners Association, Inc., (the "Association") was held on the 17th day of September, 2014; and 

WHEREAS, a quorum of the members of the Board attended said meeting; and 

WHEREAS, pursuant to a Motion duly made and approved by the Board the following resolution was 
adopted: 

WHEREAS, Article IX, Section 6 of the Enclave @ Forest Creek First Amendment and Restatement of the 
Declaration of Covenants, Conditions and Restrictions (the "Declaration") contains provisions with 
respect to the parking and storage of automobiles on a member's property and prohibits parking 
"outside of any approved garage area between any Residence and the abutting front street or between 
any Residence and an abutting side street..."; and 

WHEREAS, the Board recognizes that there may be occasions when parking of automobiles in the 
driveway of a Residence is necessary and appropriate; and 

WHEREAS, pursuant to the provisions of Article IV, Section l(k) of the Declaration, the Board has the 
authority: 

(k) To make reasonable rules and regulations for the operation of the Common Properties and 
the Association and to amend them from time to time; and 

WHEREAS, the Board has determined that it is in the best interest of the Association for the members of 
the Association to be able to utilize driveway areas on a member's property for parking of automobiles 
subject to direction by the Board regarding the manner of use of the same. 

NOW THEREFORE, BE IT RESOLVED by the Board that: 

In order to facilitate the reasonable use of a member's driveway for the parking of automobiles

of the Association’s Fine and Enforcement 

Policy, as the same may be amended from time to time. 

D. Towing. 

Association Towing. Any vehicle parked in violation of this policy may be towed at 

owner's expense in accordance with applicable law, in addition to the imposition of any 

fines. 

Signage. Notice that a vehicle parked in violation of this rule may be towed may be 

provided by posting any signage required by law. 

CANOPY AT WESTGATE GROVE 
SUPPLEMENT TO COMMUNITY MANUAL 

4878-9690-3205v.3 43424-3



2022114301 Page 8 of 8 

Notice before Towing. If no signage is posted, before towing a vehicle, the Association 

will provide the following notice to an Owner. 

Sticker on Vchicle. A conspicuous notice will first be attached to the vehicle's 
front windshield or, if the vehicle has no front windshield, to a conspicuous part 

of the vehicle stating that the vehicle is parked in violation of the Association’s 
rules. The notice will also provide the telephone number to the towing facility 

maintained by the tow operator that is answered 24 hours a day, to enable the 

owner or operator of the vehicle to locate the vehicle. 

Additional Mailed Notice. After the notice is attached to the vehicle, the 

Association or its agent will send notice by certified mail, return receipt 

requested, to the last address shown for the owner according to the vehicle 

registration records of the Texas Department of Motor Vehicles, or if the vehicle 

is registered in another state, the appropriate agency of that state. The notice will 

state that the vehicle will be towed at the expense of the owner or operator of the 

vehicle if it is not removed within fifteen days of the date the letter is 

postmarked. The notice will also provide the telephone number to the towing 

facility maintained by the tow operator that will remove the vehicle that is 

answered 24 hours a day, to enable the owner or operator of the vehicle to locate 

the vehicle.

Parking. The owners of Unit I, Unit 2, Unit 5 and Unit 6 shall each be allowed to park one vehicle 
in the parking area located in the front of the Property with access from Lightsey Road, and the 
owners of Unit 3 and Unit 4 shall each be allowed to park one vehicle in the parking area located at 
the rear of the Property with access from Cody Court. 

SECTION 5 - COMMUNITY ETIQUETTE 

5.1 Courtesy. Each occupant shall endeavor to use his or her Unit and the common elements in a 
manner calculated to respect the rights and privileges of other occupants. 

- 3 -
rahaywoo\A22258. I\Rules.2.doc 04/18/07 



5.2 Annoyance. An occupant shall avoid doing or permitting anything to be done that will annoy, 
harass, embarrass or inconvenience other occupants or their guests, or the Association's employees 
and agents. 

5. 3 Noise and Odors. Each occupant shall exercise reasonable care to avoid making or permitting to be 
made loud, disturbing or objectionable noises or noxious odors that are likely to disturb occupants of 
other Units. 

5 .4 Reception Interference. Each occupant shall avoid doing or permitting anything to be done that may 
unreasonably interfere with the television, radio, telephonic or electronic reception of others. 

5.5 Compliance with Law. Occupants may not use a Unit or any portion of the Condominiums for 
unlawful activities. Occupants shall comply with applicable laws and regulations of the United 
States and of the State of Texas, and with ordinances, rules and regulations of Austin, Texas. An 
occupant who violates this provision shall hold the Association and other Owners and occupants 
harmless from all fines, penalties, costs and prosecutions for the occupant's violation or 
noncompliance.

Y. Stone Pathways 

• Stone pathways in which loose gravel, only, is placed over non­
compacted soil are allowed, with ACC approval. These type of pathways 
currently do not contribute to impervious coverage as defined in City of 
Austin definitions of impervious coverage, per Chapter 25-8, of the 
current Watershed Protection Ordinance 

• Pathways which are constructed of impervious material, partially impervious 
material, or are constructed on compacted soil are subject to impervious cover 
limitations for the residence and the community and may only be constructed 
with ACC approval 

Z. Tree Houses 

• Tree houses or club houses located in trees are not allowed 

Section 8 - Fees 
Projects involving changes to the unit to or changes to impervious coverage shall include a fee 
of $35 with the project submission. 

The exterior modifications that include replacements listed in Section 6, above, may be 
accomplished without application or fee. 

Section 9 - Drawing Required 
In order to facilitate project approval, a "drawing to scale" is required, including 
dimensions, with all project submissions that involve impervious coverage. This is to aid 
the ACC in calculating the square area oftheproject. 

Section 10 - Variance 
An Owner may submit a request for a variance from the requirements of these Guidelines with 
an ACC application.

authorize the Association through the Board and the ACC to develop guidelines which 
supplement the declarant's original specifications in the governing documents. 

Section 3 - Organization of Topics 
Any modification or addition to construction can be specified almost entirely by its properties 
(color, size, material, texture, etc.). So, each major element of the exterior of a Unit is listed 
herein with the properties that may or may not be modified, and how so. Whenever possible, 
rationale for the decision is included. 

Section 4 - Definition of Impervious Cover 
Impervious Cover is defined in Chapter 25-8-1(11) of the Austin City Code as "the total area 
of any surface that prevents the infiltration of water into the ground, such as roads, parking 
areas, concrete, and buildings." Other items included in or excluded from Impervious Cover 
calculations are found in Chapter 25-8-63 of the Austin City Code, titled Impervious Cover 

Architectural Control Guidelines - Independence Park Condominium Community, Inc. Page2 



2021059562 Page 15 of 20 

Calculations. In general, anything that has horizontal surface area and that prevents rainwater 
from reaching the ground is considered impervious coverage. Common examples include (but 
are not limited to) decks, sheds, patios, concrete, etc. Each Unit is allotted 150 square feet of 
impervious cover in addition to the existing footprint of the Unit as of DA TE OF 
RECORDING. 

Section 5 - Responsibility 
It is the responsibility of the Owner to ensure the Guidelines are adhered to for his or her Unit 
and to ensure any exterior modification to the Unit is well-maintained. Owners must maintain 
records of impervious cover additions to their Units in terms of total square footage and not 
exceed the amount allocated to each Unit as provided herein. Owners must assist the ACC in

Section 1 - Purpose 
Pursuant to the Resolution of the Board of Directors of the Independence Park Condominium 
Community, Inc., recorded under Document No. 2012212132 of the Official Public Records 
of Travis County, Texas (the "Resolution") there was formed an Architectural Control 
Committee ("ACC") which is governed by a Charter found in the appendix to the Resolution. 
The ACC was established to set guidelines to help govern the appearance of the community 
and to facilitate compliance with the Declaration of Condominium Regime for Independence 
Park Condominiums (A Residential Condominium in Travis County, Texas), recorded under 
Document No. 2007059517 of the Official Public Records of Travis County, Texas as it has 
been or may be amended from time to time (the "Declaration") and other governing 
documents oflndependence Park Condominium Community, Inc. (the "Association"), which 
include but are not limited to the Independence Park Community Manual, recorded under

Independence Park Condominiums First Amendment to Rules and Regulations, recorded 
under Document No. 2007230444 of the Official Public Records of Travis County, Texas, the 
Independence Park Condominiums Second Amendment to Rules and Regulations, recorded 
under Document No. 2008165360 of the Official Public Records of Travis County, Texas, the 
Independence Park Condominiums Supplement to Community Manual, recorded under 
Document No. 2011149942 of the Official Public Records of Travis County, Texas, and the 
Independence Park Condominium Community, Inc. Policy regarding For Sale/For Lease 
Signs, recorded under Document No. 2014093214 of the Official Public Records of Travis 
County, Texas, as such instruments may be amended or supplemented from time to time. The 
purpose of these Architectural Control Guidelines (the "Guidelines") is to augment and clarify 
the stipulations set out in the governing documents of the Association, as they may be 
amended from time to time. 

Section 2 - Principles 
The Association must ever balance two factors. The first is the desire of Owners to be 
comfortable in their Units, express their creativity through the appearance of their Units, and 
take actions as needed to sustain and improve the relative value of their Units. The second is 
the need to ensure compliance with the governing documents of the Association and 
consistency throughout the Property. These Guidelines are designed with that purpose in mind 
and may amended from time to time as best suits this balance. The governing documents 
authorize the Association through the Board and the ACC to develop guidelines which

the ACC any Residential Permit for review prior to approval of any modifications. 

Section 6 - Modification without ACC Application 
To reduce unnecessary administration and allow for more Owner creativity, the Board and 
ACC, by approving these Guidelines, grants to the Owners the permission to complete the 
following types of exterior modifications without submission of an ACC application or fee. 

A. Installation of front entrance screen door 
• Commercial quality doors and installations are required 
• Style must complement the exterior Unit design 

B. Installation of rain gutters (without receptacle) 
• Commercial quality materials and installation are required 
• Color must complement the style of the Unit 

C. Fencing around plants or trees in the rear yard 
• Commercial quality fence materials are required 
• Height is limited to eighteen inches (18") without ACC approval 

D. Address Numerals 
• The size, shape, and style of residential address numerals affixed to a Unit 

does not require ACC approval 
• Residential address numerals on curb area will be maintained by the HOA. 

E. Garage Doors 
• May be replaced with doors of the same style used in original construction only 

(including windows) without ACC approval. 
• Must be painted primary color of the unit. 

F. House Exterior Color 
• Re-painting a Unit in the same color(s) is permitted without ACC 

approval. 

G. Common Area Fence 
• Material is restricted to four inch ( 4") wooden slats (pickets). Fence pickets

documents.content:
Introduction 
 
These guidelines are an effort to simplify acceptance of your proposed 
improvements on, and use of your property in Green Haven Ranch.  Following these 
guidelines does not guarantee approval by the Architectural Committee (ARC) but 
gives you the greatest chance of approval without undue work and additional 
requests for information. 
 
 

Signs 
 
The following signs are generally acceptable as long as they don’t exceed 6 square 
feet in area: 
 

 Builder Signs 
 For Sale Signs 
 Academic Signs 
 Political Signs 

 
 

Outbuildings – Permanent & Portable 
 
Outbuildings under 121 square feet, less than 7 feet tall and behind a privacy 
fence and/or generally out of public view can be made of any material.  
 
 
Between 121 and 700 square feet and NOT considered living quarters 
 

 Roofing material of either shingles or metal 

 Exterior walls constructed of brick, stone, stucco, cement board, wood siding 
or vinyl siding 

 Coloring that is consistent with main structure 

 Is situated on the property in such a manner so as not to detract from the 
residential character of the property 

 
NOTE: If the same roofing materials as the main structure are used, then the roofing 
should match the main structure 
 
 
Greater than 700 square feet or considered additional living quarters 
 

 Must be on a slab foundation 
 Must be 75% masonry and be consistent with main structure 

 Roofing material must match main structure 



 Color must be consistent with main structure 

 Is situated on the property in such a manner so as not to detract from the 
residential character of the property 
 

 
NOTE: If there are multiple outbuildings greater than 120 square feet, it is 
recommended that the buildings be consistent with one another. 
 
 

Landscaping 
 
Care should be exercised in the landscaping and in planting and maintenance of 
trees and shrubs on the property to prevent drainage problems or obstruction of

Plant & Tree Beds 
• May be fenced, lined with stone, plant material, or bed edging with ACC 

approval 

Architectural Control Guidelines - Independence Park Condominium Community, Inc. Page4 



2021059562 Page 17 of 20 

F. Front Door 
• Color may be changed with ACC approval 

G. Front Porch Fence, Gate & Screen allowed, with ACC approval 
• An iron fence, and/or fence made of metal material that is either powder- coated 

or anodized is allowed, with ACC approval. In all cases the railings dimensions 
shall be one inch (l ") x one inch (l ") or less 

• A gate of the same material and height as the fence is allowed, with ACC 
approval 

• A gate latch which can be opened from either side is allowed, with ACC 
approval 

• In all cases, fence and/or gate height may not exceed 42" above the front 
patio deck 

• Painted metal or vinyl-covered metal is not allowed as a fence or gate 
material 

• Front porches may not be screened 

H. Rear Patio Screening 
• Rear patios may be enclosed by a screen enclosure, with ACC approval 
• Plans for an enclosure must include an exit door that opens to the outside. 

I. Garage Door 

• Any replacement garage door that differs in design from the one installed with 
original construction requires ACC approval 

• Reason: the garage door style is part of the general design of the community 

J. Common Area Yard Fence 

• Fences may be painted or colored differently on sides not visible from the 
street, with ACCapproval 

• Fence height is restricted to six feet (6') maximum, except where the 
developer has previously permitted a variance for a different height or 
additional lattice-work. Changing a fence structure is with ACC approval, 
only. 

K. Property Perimeter Fence 

• Any alteration from original design or color requires ACC approval 

• Reason: often these fences abut city and the greater community, and a 
pleasant and consistent image is desired to be projected 

L. Waste/Recycle Bin Fences or Facades

documents.content:
July 12, 2022

Meeting called to order by Dana Putska at 6:33
Minutes approved from last meeting Dana, Brenda seconded


Old Business
*Recycle Bins & Dumpster- Brenda reminded the community about the rules surrounding the dumpsters and the recycling bins. Put trash in bags and push it in the dumpster and hit the button.  We are doing better but still need to improve.
*Parking- Brenda alerted the community that the parking changes have been completed.  We have removed a couple of handicap parking spaces to accommodate more guest spots.
*Gate Repair- Dana let the community know that Matt has completed the repairs to the gate.

New Business
*Monthly Board walk-through- the board walks the property once per month.  They notate any damage that they see so we can stay ahead of the maintenance. 
*Pool- dana reminded the community to close the umbrellas. We are getting bids to resurface the pool deck. Looking to do it in the fall/winter.
*Erosion-Matt is going to install the edging along the side and front where there is erosion. After that, we will bring in the rocks to build it up. 
*Exterior Painting- Getting bids for all exterior doors and garage doors. We are going away from the brown but not completely. 
*New Landscaping Company- We will no longer be using LandCare. We have hired Urban Dirt and they will begin on August 1st.  A meeting will take place with a walk-through so Urban Dirt will be creating a 3-5 year plan. 
*All Saints- They have applied for a variance to put in a soccer field to the west of Vista Hills.  Brenda has sent them a list of questions we have as a community.  Brenda has also reached out to the other condo complex, and they have the same questions. 
*Financials- Kristy updated the community on the financials
*AppFolio Usage- Jackie let the community know that we had 71 new maintenance requests over the last 90 days.  37 work orders have been completed and closed out 11 are brand new in the last 2 days and they rest are in progress.

documents.content:
Highland Lake Villas Homeowners Rules & Regulations

Rules and Regulations
Parking and Storage of Vehicles
1. Each unit shall have the use on only two parking spaces. All parking will be on a first come first served basis. 
2. No long term parking.
3. No resident shall repair or restore any vehicle of any kind in, or around the Common Areas except for emergency repairs (48 hr limit) 
4. Only currently registered vehicles may be parked in parking lot. 
Vehicles found in violation of any of the rules in this section are subject to fines as well as towing at the vehicle owners expense. 
Insurance
1. Unit owners shall purchase and maintain a homeowner’s Policy with respect to their individual unit. 
Architectural Control
1. No owner, lessee, or guest shall deface or demolish common property in any way.
Association Dues
1. Association dues are due on the first day of each month, and delinquent if not received on or before the 10th day of the month. 
Animals
1. No more than two (2) domesticated dogs/cats or other small household pets may be kept in any unit. 
2. Pets must not be left unattended (i.e., the owner must be outside with pet) and pets must be on a leash at all times when outside the unit. 
3. Owners are responsible for cleaning up after their pets in any Common Area and are also personally responsible for the cost to repair any damage caused by their pets to the Common Area.  
4. Animal bites must be reported to the Lago Vista Animal Control. 
Nuisance 
1. Unclean, unhealthy, unsightly, or unkempt conditions in, on, or about the Units patios and porches are prohibited. 
2. Children should not be left unattended. Parents are responsible for any damages or injuries that may occur. 
3. The storage of any item, property, or thing that will cause the Unit or Common Area to appear to be unclean or untidy or that will be noxious to the senses is prohibited.

Highland Lake Villas Homeowners Rules & Regulations 

 

Rules and Regulations 
Parking and Storage of Vehicles 

1. Each unit shall have the use on only two parking spaces. All parking will be on a first come first 
served basis.  

2. No long term parking. 
3. No resident shall repair or restore any vehicle of any kind in, or around the Common Areas 

except for emergency repairs (48 hr limit)  
4. Only currently registered vehicles may be parked in parking lot.  

Vehicles found in violation of any of the rules in this section are subject to fines as well as towing at the 
vehicle owners expense.  

Insurance 

1. Unit owners shall purchase and maintain a homeowner’s Policy with respect to their individual 
unit.  

Architectural Control 

1. No owner, lessee, or guest shall deface or demolish common property in any way. 

Association Dues 

1. Association dues are due on the first day of each month, and delinquent if not received on or 
before the 10th day of the month.  

Animals 

1. No more than two (2) domesticated dogs/cats or other small household pets may be kept in any 
unit.  

2. Pets must not be left unattended (i.e., the owner must be outside with pet) and pets must be on a 
leash at all times when outside the unit.  

3. Owners are responsible for cleaning up after their pets in any Common Area and are also 
personally responsible for the cost to repair any damage caused by their pets to the Common 
Area.   

4. Animal bites must be reported to the Lago Vista Animal Control.  

Nuisance  

1. Unclean, unhealthy, unsightly, or unkempt conditions in, on, or about the Units patios and 
porches are prohibited.  

2. Children should not be left unattended. Parents are responsible for any damages or injuries that 
may occur.  

3. The storage of any item, property, or thing that will cause the Unit or Common Area to appear to 
be unclean or untidy or that will be noxious to the senses is prohibited.

documents.content:
July 12, 2022

Meeting called to order by Dana Putska at 6:33
Minutes approved from last meeting Dana, Brenda seconded


Old Business
*Recycle Bins & Dumpster- Brenda reminded the community about the rules surrounding the dumpsters and the recycling bins. Put trash in bags and push it in the dumpster and hit the button.  We are doing better but still need to improve.
*Parking- Brenda alerted the community that the parking changes have been completed.  We have removed a couple of handicap parking spaces to accommodate more guest spots.
*Gate Repair- Dana let the community know that Matt has completed the repairs to the gate.

New Business
*Monthly Board walk-through- the board walks the property once per month.  They notate any damage that they see so we can stay ahead of the maintenance. 
*Pool- dana reminded the community to close the umbrellas. We are getting bids to resurface the pool deck. Looking to do it in the fall/winter.
*Erosion-Matt is going to install the edging along the side and front where there is erosion. After that, we will bring in the rocks to build it up. 
*Exterior Painting- Getting bids for all exterior doors and garage doors. We are going away from the brown but not completely. 
*New Landscaping Company- We will no longer be using LandCare. We have hired Urban Dirt and they will begin on August 1st.  A meeting will take place with a walk-through so Urban Dirt will be creating a 3-5 year plan. 
*All Saints- They have applied for a variance to put in a soccer field to the west of Vista Hills.  Brenda has sent them a list of questions we have as a community.  Brenda has also reached out to the other condo complex, and they have the same questions. 
*Financials- Kristy updated the community on the financials
*AppFolio Usage- Jackie let the community know that we had 71 new maintenance requests over the last 90 days.  37 work orders have been completed and closed out 11 are brand new in the last 2 days and they rest are in progress.

1. General. The following rule outlines the restrictions applicable to religious displays in order to permit them 

while also striving to maintain an aesthetically harmonious and peaceful neighborhood for all neighbors to 
enjoy. Allowed religious displays are limited to displays motivated by the resident’s sincere religious belief*. 

2. Prohibited Items. No religious item(s) displayed may: : 
a. threaten the public health or safety; 
b. violate a law?; 
c. contain language, graphics, or any display that is patently offensive to a passerby; 
d. beinstalled on property owned or maintained by the association (including common elements); 
e. be installed on property owned in common by two or more members of the association; 

f. be located in violation of any applicable building line, right of way, setback, or easement; or 
g. be attached to a traffic control device, street lamp, fire hydrant, or utility sign, pole, or fixture, 

3. Parameters. Displays may not be located outside of the Unit (no displays are allowed in the common 
elements) with the exception of one display on any exterior door or door frame of the home that is 25 square 
inches or smaller. For example, and without limitation, no prior permission is required from the association 
to place a cross, mezuzah, or other similar religious symbol smaller than 25 square inches on the home’s 
front door or door frame. If the dedicatory instruments do not designate an architectural reviewing body (such

1. The Chandler Creek HOA swimming pool is a SWIM AT YOUR OWN RISK pool.  No lifeguards are on duty.  Children 
under the age of 16 must be accompanied by a Chandler Creek HOA resident 18 years of age or older.  This rule is 
strictly enforced. 

2. Use of any facility and/or equipment in the pool area is at your discretion. Please use caution. 

3. All Chandler Creek HOA residents are required to show their pool access pass device and a valid State of Texas ID if 
requested by a Pool Monitor.  Failure to comply may result in you being asked to leave the pool area. 

4. The access gates can only be opened with your assigned pool access device.  Gates are to remain closed/locked at all 
times.  The Pool Monitors have been instructed not to open the gate for anyone without a pool access device.  Anyone 
without a pool access device will be asked to retrieve theirs before they will be allowed to enter the pool area.  Under 
no circumstances should the gate(s) be propped open.  There is a $20 replacement fee for lost/defective pool access 
devices. 

5. One household may host up to four (4) pool guests.  All pool guests must be accompanied by a Chandler Creek HOA 
resident who remains at the pool during the guest’s visit. 

6. Chandler Creek homeowners have the authority to always enforce the current pool rules.  Conduct by any person 
deemed to be dangerous, unreasonable, or offensive (including “horseplay”) is not allowed and should be reported to 
the Pool Monitor.  Any individual disciplined repeatedly, or for serious infractions, may lose all pool privileges for the 
rest of the season. 

7. The kiddy pool is limited to children 5 years of age and younger.  Exceptions may be made for older children with injuries 
which would prevent them from safely entering the main pool.  Each child in the kiddy pool must have an adult 
supervisor;

La Ventana Clubhouse Rental Rules, Regulations and Pool Rules 3



La Ventana Ranch Owners Association
Pool Rules

October 1, 2023

● The LaVentana swimming pools are SWIM AT YOUR OWN RISK pools.

● The swimming pools are for the use of the ROA Members and their invited guests only.

● Pool hours are from 6 am - 10 pm. Maximum guests per household is 12.

● Pools may not be used along with a clubhouse reservation or rental. Pools remain open to residents
at all times

● Leave gates closed. DO NOT prop them open.

● Noise must be kept to a minimum and any music turned off by 9:00 pm.

● Pool furniture cannot be removed from the pool area.

● NO DIVING allowed anywhere in the pool area. No jumping off ledge between the pools.

Restrooms:  The restroom fixtures are sanitized and cleaned by a private janitorial service.  The designated maintenance

the restroom should require attention, please notify the Pool Monitor on duty or call the current HOA management 
company. 

Penalties for Violation of Pool Rules: 

Depending on upon severity of offense, action taken by the HOA for violation of HOA pool rues may include one or more of 
the following: 

• 1st offense – A written warning is issued (notification of registered homeowner, parent, or guardian, when 
applicable) 

• 2nd offense – A second written warning is issued. 

• 3rd offense – Pool privileges are revoked, and pool card deactivated.

and must always be accompanied by an adult within arm’s length.  Children wearing regular diapers are not allowed in 
either the main pool or the kiddy pool.  “Swim” diapers must always be used.  If your child or anyone else in your party 
is found to be responsible for a closure due to fecal matter, all costs to clean and reopen the pool may be assigned to 
your household via your HOA account.  If a fecal accident occurs: All swimmers must exit the pool immediately and the 
pool will be closed for the minimum time frame as allowed by law from the time the pool has been chemically treated.  
Incidents should be immediately reported to the current HOA management company and/or the Pool Monitor on duty. 

17. Persons having currently active diarrhea or who have had active diarrhea within the previous 14 days are not allowed to 
enter the pool water. 

18. No smoking or any other use of tobacco products (Skoal, chewing tobacco, vapor cigarettes, etc.).  The following are not 
permitted in the pool area or surrounding park under any circumstances: alcohol, firearms, or drugs.  Individuals 
engaging in the use of such are subject to loss of privileges for a period to be determined by the HOA Board. Other legal 
actions may be taken in conjunction with the Williamson County Sheriff’s Office. 

19. Swim safely and treat others as you would like to be treated.  Residents are responsible for the behavior of those in their 
household and/or their guests. 

20. In the event of inclement weather, swimmers are to clear the pool during the storm and for at least thirty (30) minutes 
after lightning and/or thunder has ceased. 

21. Any resident may call the current HOA management company to report unsafe behavior or violations of pool rules they 
witness.

documents.content:
kept to a minimum and any music turned off by 9:00 pm.

● Pool furniture cannot be removed from the pool area.

● NO DIVING allowed anywhere in the pool area. No jumping off ledge between the pools.

● The pools are shallow and diving and jumping off sides can cause injury.

● Running in the pool area is prohibited.

● No person under the age of 15 will be allowed at any time unless accompanied and supervised by an
adult.

● Non-swimmers of any age must be accompanied in the water by a responsible person within arms
reach.

● It is recommended that non swimmers wear some type of flotation device while in the pool.

● Proper swim attire is required (no cut offs allowed ).

● Children who are not toilet trained must wear a proper swim diaper, as well as a vinyl or plastic
diaper cover. Pull Ups and Swim Diapers do not hold urine and or feces and are not allowed.

● No glass containers of any type are allowed in the pool area.

● Pets and any type of motorized vehicles are not allowed in the pool area.

● Pool area is monitored with security cameras.

● No firearms or weapons of any type are allowed in the pool area.

● Members are responsible for replacing furniture when they move it.

● Members are responsible for cleaning up after themselves when using the pool area. There is no paid
Service company that comes to clean the pool area.

● Members are responsible for removing any items that they brought to the pool area.

documents.content:
La Ventana Ranch Owners Association
Clubhouse Rental Rules, Regulations and Pool Rules

October 1, 2023

The following rules shall govern rentals of the Clubhouse for private events.

Reserved Space: A La Ventana Ranch Owners Association Member ROA Member (“ROA Member”), may
reserve the Clubhouse for a private event. In the context of rentals, the “Clubhouse” is the space that includes
the sitting room with fireplace, main room with TV and pool table, kitchen, restrooms and pavilion. It does not
include the pool, spas, exercise rooms, playground, tennis courts, golf range, and creek areas. These areas are
not available for reserving and shall remain available to all La Ventana Residents during any private event at
the Clubhouse.

Pool Usage: Pool usage during an event in which the clubhouse has been reserved / rented is NOT
allowed. ROA Members are responsible for their invited guests and that they follow rules. The LaVentana
Homeowners Association will not be responsible for any injuries for members and or their guests while using
The clubhouse, pools and surrounding areas. The ROA Members using the pools are responsible for any
damages that may occur while they or their invited guests are using the pool.

Access. Only a ROA Member may rent the clubhouse.
(a) The ROA Member must be in good standing at the time the reservation is made and at the date and time in
which the event takes place. Should the ROA Member not be in good standing, the Homeowners Association
reserves the right to not allow the event to take place. .
(b) The ROA Member shall access the clubhouse with their assigned key card. The ROA member must be
present at all times during any use of the clubhouse and shall be personally responsible for the behavior of their
guests. If an ROA Member is not present at all times during their event, deposit shall be forfeited.
(c) All persons under the age of 15 must be supervised by an adult while at the clubhouse.

documents.content:
tables and chairs must be wiped clean.
(c) The kitchen must be properly cleaned and returned to its original condition. Any food brought in must be
removed from the refrigerator and or freezer.
(d) Trash cans indoors and outdoors are to be emptied and trash placed in the trash bins located in parking lot.
(e) Restrooms trash cans emptied and countertops wiped down.
(f) All furniture must be returned to its original position.
(g) All greenery, flowers, decorations and other items brought in must be removed.
(h) Pavilion, if used, should be swept, all trash cans emptied and furniture put back to its original place.
(i) All lights, appliances and fans must be turned off.
Failure to strictly comply with the cleaning requirements will result in forfeit of security deposit.

Damages: The ROA Member will be held responsible for any damage caused by the member and or their
guests. The breach or violation of any condition set forth herein may result in the loss of the security deposit,
the imposition of liability on the ROA Member, and possible denial of future rentals of the Clubhouse.

Right of Refusal: The Association reserves the right to refuse to rent the facilities for any purpose it deems to
be detrimental to or not in the best interests of its members. It further reserves the right to refuse to rent the
facilities on any dates and at any time it deems inappropriate or inconvenient to residents of La Ventana.

La Ventana Ranch Owners Association
Pool Rules

October 1, 2023

● The LaVentana swimming pools are SWIM AT YOUR OWN RISK pools.

● The swimming pools are for the use of the ROA Members and their invited guests only.

● Pool hours are from 6 am - 10 pm. Maximum guests per household is 12.

● Pools may not be used along with a clubhouse reservation or rental. Pools remain open to residents
at all times

● Leave gates closed. DO NOT prop them open.

(f) No oil drilling, oil development operation, oil refining, quarrying or 
mining operations of any kind shall be permitted on the surface of the Property. No oil 
wells, tanks, tunnels, mineral excavations or shafts shall be permitted upon or in any part 
of the Property. No derrick or other structure designed for use in quarrying or boring for 
oil, natural gas or other minerals shall be erected, maintained or permitted on the 
Property. 

(g) No animals, livestock, fowl or poultry of any kind shall be raised, bred or 
kept on the Property, except that dogs, cats or other household pets may be kept for the 
purpose of providing companionship for the private family. Animals are notto be raised, 
bred or kept for commercial purposes or for food. It is the purpose of these provisions to 
restrict the use of the Property so that no person shall quarter on any part of the Property 
cows, horses, bees, pigeons, hogs, sheep, goats, guinea fowls, ducks, chickens, turkeys, 
skunks or any other animals that may interfere with the quietude, health or safety of the 
community. No more than three pets will be permitted on each Lot. Pets must be 
restrained or confined to the rear of the Owner's Lot inside a fenced area or Vlithin the 
house. It is the pet owner's responsibility to keep the Lot clean and free of pet debris. All 
animals must be properly tagged for identification and vaccinated against rabies. 

(h) No Lot or other area on the Property shall be used as a dumping ground 
for rubbish or a site for the accumulation of unsightly materials of any kind, including, 
but not limited to, broken or rusty equipment, disassembled or inoperative cars and 
discarded appliances and furniture. Trash, garbage or other waste shall not be kept 
except in sanitary containers. All equipment for the storage or other disposal of such 
material shall be kept in clean and sanitary condition. All containers and other facilities

The following restrictions apply to signs advertising a political candidate or ballot item for an 
election, as described in Chapter 202: 

a. The signs may be displayed only during the period beginning 90 days before the date of the election to 
which the sign relates and ending 10 days after that election date. 

b. Only one sign for each candidate or ballot item may be displayed at each residence, and no sign may 
be larger than four feet by six feet. 

c. Each sign must be ground-mounted, and no sign may (i) contains roofing material, siding, paving 
materials, flora, one or more balloons or lights, or any other similar building, landscaping, or nonstandard 
decorative component, (ii) be attached in any way to plant material, a traffic control device, a light, a 
trailer, a vehicle, or any other existing structure or object, (iii) include the painting of architectural 
surfaces, (iv) threaten the public health or safety, (v) violate a law, (vi) contain language, graphics, or 
any display that would be offensive to the ordinary person, or (vii) be accompanied by music or other 
sounds, by streamers, or otherwise be distracting to motorists. 

d. The Association may remove a sign displayed in violation of these standards. 

12. Lights: states, " ... No holiday or occasion lighting or decorations shall be installed earlier than 
thirty (30) days prior to occasion and must be removed no later than twenty (20) days after the event. 

13. Disposal of Trash: states, "All rubbish, trash, garbage or other waste shall be kept in sanitary 
containers and out of sight of the Common Area and any street or adjacent Lot, except on days designated 
. .. for pick-up of such garbage." 

14. Animals and Livestock: states, "No more than three (3) pets shall be kept on a Lot. All pets must be 
properly tagged for identification ... No pet may be chained or leashed outside an enclosure unless being 
walked on a leash.

documents.content:
ChimneyHill Residents
IMPORTANT REMINDER REGARDING PETS
In accordance with the ChimneyHill Community Deed Restrictions, all pets must be controlled so as not to imperil the safety of others or create a nuisance, a disturbance or damage to any property with the community.  All pets must be on a leash and always controlled by the owner (NOT STAKED) while outdoors.
It is the responsibility of the pet owner to pick up and properly dispose of ALL animal waste while outdoors with their pets.  Individual Homeowner lots are not approved pet walking areas and should be avoided for animal defecation.   Approved pet walking areas are the Hiking Trail and the area north of Wimbledon Drive.   
Please be courteous to your neighbors and keep our community safe and clean by being RESPONSIBLE for your pets.

82.102(a) of the Texas Uniform Condominium Act; and 

 
WHEREAS the Association has voted to amend the Initial Rules and Regulations attached to the Community 
Manual (the “Rules”) as follows: 

 
1. Rule C-3 is ADDED to the Rules (“Monthly Rental Fee”) to read in its entirety as follows: 

 

“C-3.   Monthly Rental Fee.  Owners of units being leased shall pay to the Association a fee in 
the amount of $75 per month per leased unit (e.g. if an owner owns two units and leases 
one unit, the Monthly Rental Fee is $75. If the same owner leases two units, the Monthly 
Rental Fee is $150). Monthly Rental Fees are due on the 15th day of each calendar 
month.” 

 
2. Rule J-2 (“Permitted Pets”) is AMENDED and RESTATED to read in its entirety as follows: 

 

“Permitted Pets. Subject to these Rules, a resident may keep in his unit customary domesticated 
house pets, such as domesticated dogs, cats, caged birds, and aquarium fish, provided there are not 
more than two cats, or two dogs, or one cat and one dog.” 

 
3. Rule J-3 (“Prohibited Animals”) is AMENDED and RESTATED to read in its entirety as follows: 

 

“Prohibited Animals. No resident may keep a dangerous or exotic animal, trained attack dog, or 
any other animal deemed by the Board to be a potential threat to the well-being of people or other 
animals. No animal or house pet may be kept, bred, or maintained for any commercial purpose.

Document reference. Reference is hereby made to the Declaration of Condominium Regime of Macmora Cottages, 
a Condominium, filed as Document No. 2005173033 in the Official Public Records of Travis County, Texas 
(together with all amendments and supplements thereto, the “Declaration”). 

Reference is further made to the “Bylaws of Macmora Cottages HOA, Inc.”, attached as Exhibit “B” to the 
Declaration (together with all amendments and supplements thereto, the “Bylaws”).

documents.content:
July 12, 2022

Meeting called to order by Dana Putska at 6:33
Minutes approved from last meeting Dana, Brenda seconded


Old Business
*Recycle Bins & Dumpster- Brenda reminded the community about the rules surrounding the dumpsters and the recycling bins. Put trash in bags and push it in the dumpster and hit the button.  We are doing better but still need to improve.
*Parking- Brenda alerted the community that the parking changes have been completed.  We have removed a couple of handicap parking spaces to accommodate more guest spots.
*Gate Repair- Dana let the community know that Matt has completed the repairs to the gate.

New Business
*Monthly Board walk-through- the board walks the property once per month.  They notate any damage that they see so we can stay ahead of the maintenance. 
*Pool- dana reminded the community to close the umbrellas. We are getting bids to resurface the pool deck. Looking to do it in the fall/winter.
*Erosion-Matt is going to install the edging along the side and front where there is erosion. After that, we will bring in the rocks to build it up. 
*Exterior Painting- Getting bids for all exterior doors and garage doors. We are going away from the brown but not completely. 
*New Landscaping Company- We will no longer be using LandCare. We have hired Urban Dirt and they will begin on August 1st.  A meeting will take place with a walk-through so Urban Dirt will be creating a 3-5 year plan. 
*All Saints- They have applied for a variance to put in a soccer field to the west of Vista Hills.  Brenda has sent them a list of questions we have as a community.  Brenda has also reached out to the other condo complex, and they have the same questions. 
*Financials- Kristy updated the community on the financials
*AppFolio Usage- Jackie let the community know that we had 71 new maintenance requests over the last 90 days.  37 work orders have been completed and closed out 11 are brand new in the last 2 days and they rest are in progress.

documents.content:
Highland Lake Villas Homeowners Rules & Regulations 

 

Rules and Regulations 
Parking and Storage of Vehicles 

1. Each unit shall have the use on only two parking spaces. All parking will be on a first come first 
served basis.  

2. No long term parking. 
3. No resident shall repair or restore any vehicle of any kind in, or around the Common Areas 

except for emergency repairs (48 hr limit)  
4. Only currently registered vehicles may be parked in parking lot.  

Vehicles found in violation of any of the rules in this section are subject to fines as well as towing at the 
vehicle owners expense.  

Insurance 

1. Unit owners shall purchase and maintain a homeowner’s Policy with respect to their individual 
unit.  

Architectural Control 

1. No owner, lessee, or guest shall deface or demolish common property in any way. 

Association Dues 

1. Association dues are due on the first day of each month, and delinquent if not received on or 
before the 10th day of the month.  

Animals 

1. No more than two (2) domesticated dogs/cats or other small household pets may be kept in any 
unit.  

2. Pets must not be left unattended (i.e., the owner must be outside with pet) and pets must be on a 
leash at all times when outside the unit.  

3. Owners are responsible for cleaning up after their pets in any Common Area and are also 
personally responsible for the cost to repair any damage caused by their pets to the Common 
Area.   

4. Animal bites must be reported to the Lago Vista Animal Control.  

Nuisance  

1. Unclean, unhealthy, unsightly, or unkempt conditions in, on, or about the Units patios and 
porches are prohibited.  

2. Children should not be left unattended. Parents are responsible for any damages or injuries that 
may occur.  

3. The storage of any item, property, or thing that will cause the Unit or Common Area to appear to 
be unclean or untidy or that will be noxious to the senses is prohibited.

documents.content:
Highland Lake Villas Homeowners Rules & Regulations

Rules and Regulations
Parking and Storage of Vehicles
1. Each unit shall have the use on only two parking spaces. All parking will be on a first come first served basis. 
2. No long term parking.
3. No resident shall repair or restore any vehicle of any kind in, or around the Common Areas except for emergency repairs (48 hr limit) 
4. Only currently registered vehicles may be parked in parking lot. 
Vehicles found in violation of any of the rules in this section are subject to fines as well as towing at the vehicle owners expense. 
Insurance
1. Unit owners shall purchase and maintain a homeowner’s Policy with respect to their individual unit. 
Architectural Control
1. No owner, lessee, or guest shall deface or demolish common property in any way.
Association Dues
1. Association dues are due on the first day of each month, and delinquent if not received on or before the 10th day of the month. 
Animals
1. No more than two (2) domesticated dogs/cats or other small household pets may be kept in any unit. 
2. Pets must not be left unattended (i.e., the owner must be outside with pet) and pets must be on a leash at all times when outside the unit. 
3. Owners are responsible for cleaning up after their pets in any Common Area and are also personally responsible for the cost to repair any damage caused by their pets to the Common Area.  
4. Animal bites must be reported to the Lago Vista Animal Control. 
Nuisance 
1. Unclean, unhealthy, unsightly, or unkempt conditions in, on, or about the Units patios and porches are prohibited. 
2. Children should not be left unattended. Parents are responsible for any damages or injuries that may occur. 
3. The storage of any item, property, or thing that will cause the Unit or Common Area to appear to be unclean or untidy or that will be noxious to the senses is prohibited.

Vehicle Condition Requirements. A vehicle must be operable, and must display a 

current license tag or plate, and inspection sticker. An “inoperable” vehicle is one that is 

obviously or actually not capable of being operated as a vehicle. Each vehicle must be 

maintained and operated to minimize noise, odor, and oil emissions. No vehicle may be 

parked in the Common Elements if the Board deems it to be unsightly, inoperable, 

inappropriate, or otherwise in violation of these rules. 

Violations. A vehicle in violation of these Rules may be stickered/ticketed, wheel-locked, 

towed, or otherwise removed from the Property by the Board, at the expense of the 

vehicle's owner. The Association expressly disclaims any liability for damage to vehicles 

on which the Association exercises these remedies for Rules violations. 

C. Enforcement. 

Interpretation. In the event of any dispute regarding the effect or application of this 

policy, the interpretation of the Board of Directors (the “Board”) will be final. 

Nuisance. Every act or omission whereby any provision of this policy is violated, in 

whole or in part, is hereby declared to be a nuisance. 

Self-Help. A vehicle in violation of this policy may be towed, by or at the direction of the 

Association, at the expense of the vehicle’s owner. The Association expressly disclaims 

any liability for damage to vehicles on which the Association exercises these remedies 

for violations of this policy. 

Fines. The Association may impose fines for violation of the provisions of this policy 

pursuant to the provisions and procedures of the Association’s Fine and Enforcement 

Policy, as the same may be amended from time to time. 

D. Towing. 

Association Towing. Any vehicle parked in violation of this policy may be towed at

documents.content:
only. At no time shall an Owner or 

a tenant use a visitor parking space. Guests who occupy a Unit overnight shall 

not use visitor parking spaces. Visitor parking spaces are limited to a maximum 

of four (4) hours in any twenty-four (24) hour period. 

PARKING RULES 

A, Designated Parking. 

Assigned Unit Parking. Each Unit is the subject of a recorded Assignment of Parking 

instrument that identifies the parking space or spaces designated for the exclusive use of 

a Unit (an “Assigned Space”). Owners and their tenants must use the Assigned Space 

designated for the exclusive use of the Unit they own or occupy and the parked vehicle 

must fit within the Assigned Space. Owners and their tenants may not park in any area 

or space other than the appropriate Assigned Space. 

Visitor Parking. The guest parking spaces located within the Regime are designated for 

non-resident, visitor parking only. These guest parking spaces must be shared among 

the community. These spaces may not be used for storage of vehicles and may not be 

used consistently by the same driver or vehicle. At no time shall a resident, tenant, or 

occupant use a visitor parking space. Guests who occupy a Unit overnight shall not use 

visitor parking spaces. Visitor parking spaces are limited to a maximum of four (4) hours 

in any twenty-four (24) hour period, unless otherwise approved in advance, in writing, 

by the Board.

prevents access to driveways or parking spaces. No vehicle may be parked, even 

temporarily, in fire lanes or in any area designated as "No Parking”. Vehicles parked in

3.21.2021   
  
  
  

To Enclave   at   Cooper   Lane   HOA   Board   (3)   
PS   Property   Management   (Rickey   Walker)   

  
Cc Laura   Weldon-   Resident   7404   Rook   St   
  

Subject Visitor\Guest   Parking   spots   in   Community   
  
  

Dear   Alan,   Julie   and   Bobby,     
  

First   off,   I   am   sorry   I   am   even   having   to   waste   my   time   and   yours   in   dealing   with   an   issue   such   
as   this,   but   when   something   is   being   resolved   by   our   property   manager   (Rickey),   adequately,   
but   then   I   am   told   via   email   on   3.17.2021   that   he   has   been   advised   by   the   HOA   board   to   “   stop   
all   action   being   taken   and   ignore   the   problem”.    I   now   have   to   take   matters   into   my   own   hands.   
I   don't   even   know   who   the   3   of   you   are,   other   than   via   a   zoom   meeting   once   a   year,   which   is   
fine,   so   please   do   not   take   this   personally   in   any   way.    I   have   lived   here   since   day   1,   follow   the   
rules,   don't   cause   any   issues   and   pay   my   bills-   on   time.    However,   following   rules   and   being   
fair\consistent   are   very   important   to   me.     
  

Based   on   my   above   listed   address,   you   will   know   that   I   have   very   little   visitor\guest   parking   
options   at   this   end   of   the   neighborhood-   which   is   fine-   that   is   my   problem-   I   bought   my   house   
where   I   bought   my   house.    But,   when   you   are   told   the   unassigned\unmarked   curb   spots   are   “for   
visitors   and   guests   and   on   a   first   come\first   served   basis”,   one   should   have   no   issue.    The   
problem   is   that   we   have   two   residents,   using   these   spots   for   storage   of   vehicles   that   never   
move.

documents.content:
Vista Hills Quarterly Board Meeting Agenda
April 14, 2022

All Board members were present (Mark Fisette, Brenda Jackson, Ann Bjorgo)
Meeting called to order at 6:34pm
Old Business:
· Update on Roof/Gutter Issues- Mark discussed completed roof/gutter issues and what is left to be completed
· In-Unit Water Shut-Off Valves – Jackie Price updated everyone on the status of the shut-off valves. One unit is scheduled because of an error with the plumber, 2 units have been unable to be entered so status is unknown.
· Dryer Vent Cleaning- Brenda updated the community on the dryer vent cleaning. Many participated and it was a success.
· Front and Rear Gate Repair- Matt did the welding and cleaning at the gates. Texas Central Access Control did the initial repair on the actual motor and will come out to replace the box around the cap XL system as soon as Matt puts the poles around the system for protection.
· Palm Tree Replacement at Pool- This turned out to be a significant cost to replace the palm at the same size. We will be reviewing options.
· Parking Review- Ann discussed the changes with the parking so we can accommodate more guest parking spots.

New Business:
· Recycle Bin Vandalism - Camera Installation – a new camera was installed around the dumpster and recycling bins.  We will be fining anyone who misuses or vandalizes the dumpster or bins.
· Improvement Projects- The board discussed the projects that they will be working on going forward. Landscaping is a priority, painting of the doors/garage doors.
· Insurance Renewal- Gated Texas talked about the insurance renewal.  We were able to get renewed with our current insurance company, but we did change brokers.  There was a significant increase in premium due to the freeze. When the policy was shopped around, we found that many companies would not bid on the property for various reasons.  One being the amount of roofline, another that companies do not want to take on condominium units.
·

WHEREAS, the Board established an Architectural Control Committee (the "ACC") as 
provided in that Resolution of the Board of Directors of Independence Park Condominium 
Community, Inc. in Connection with the Creation of and Appointments to the Architectural 
Control Committee by the Board of Directors of the Association, recorded under Travis County 
Clerk's File No. 2012212132 and the Architectural Control Committee Charter attached thereto as 
Exhibit A (the "Charter"); and 

WHEREAS, the Charter provides in Section 2 that the ACC may adopt such design 
guidelines and procedural and substantive rules, standards, and policies not in conflict with the 



2021059562 Page 12 of 20 

Declaration as it may deem necessary or proper for the performance of its duties and the orderly 
development of the Property; and 

WHEREAS, the Board, which presently acts as the ACC, desires to adopt these 
Architectural Control Guidelines in order to promote the purpose and standards of the 
architectural covenants and control as provided in Section 10 the Declaration. 

WITNESS ETH 

NOW, THEREFORE, BE IT RESOLVED THAT the Architectural Control Guidelines 
attached hereto are hereby adopted by the Board of Directors of the Association and shall be 
binding on all Owners, Residents, and Property within Independence Park Condominiums. 

I hereby certify, as Secretary of Independence Park Condominium Community, Inc., that 
the Architectural Control Guidelines of Indeyendence Park Condominium Community, Inc. were 
approved on the / D fl, day of lb 4-?c,L , 2021, at meeting of the Board of Directors at 
which a quorum was present.

purposes, without ACC approval 

• Shared fence must good neighbor design 
• Fences that abut trail feature must be good neighbor and no taller than six 

feet (6') 
• Fences that abut trail feature must not have a mounted advertising placard with 

the fence vendor's name 

H. Front Porch Patio Surface 
• May be sealed or stained, tiled, or fitted with stone work, without ACC 

approval 

I. Roofing Materials 

• Asphalt shingles of the same style and design and color as original materials 
are allowed, without ACC approval 

Section 7 - Guidelines for Project Approval 
Allowed exterior modifications listed in this section may only be made after approval has 
been received in writing from the ACC, upon submission of a project to the Architectural 
Control Committee. 

A. Antennas & Cable installations 
• Allowed as far out of public view as possible, and in accordance with 

Section 11.17 of the Declaration, with ACC approval 

B. Pedestrian Sidewalk - (Right of Way) 
• May not be sealed, stained, painted, or colored* 
• May not be lined with edging material of any type 

* Unless the community decides to do so as a whole 

C. Driveway 
• May not be sealed, stained, painted, or colored 
• May not be lined with edging material of any type causing interference 

with mowing 
• May not be expanded 

D. Personal Sidewalk 
• May not be painted. May not be lined with edging material of anytype 
• May be etched and stained, with ACC approval 
• May have stone work applied, with ACC approval 
• Reason: to avoid interference with the lawn maintenance service 

E. Front-Yard Plant & Tree Beds 
• May be fenced, lined with stone, plant material, or bed edging with ACC 

approval

documents.content:
plus (15'+) driveway, with ACC 
approval 

Y. Stone Pathways 

• Stone pathways in which loose gravel, only, is placed over non­
compacted soil are allowed, with ACC approval. These type of pathways 
currently do not contribute to impervious coverage as defined in City of 
Austin definitions of impervious coverage, per Chapter 25-8, of the 
current Watershed Protection Ordinance 

• Pathways which are constructed of impervious material, partially impervious 
material, or are constructed on compacted soil are subject to impervious cover 
limitations for the residence and the community and may only be constructed 
with ACC approval 

Z. Tree Houses 

• Tree houses or club houses located in trees are not allowed 

Section 8 - Fees 
Projects involving changes to the unit to or changes to impervious coverage shall include a fee 
of $35 with the project submission. 

The exterior modifications that include replacements listed in Section 6, above, may be 
accomplished without application or fee. 

Section 9 - Drawing Required 
In order to facilitate project approval, a "drawing to scale" is required, including 
dimensions, with all project submissions that involve impervious coverage. This is to aid 
the ACC in calculating the square area oftheproject. 

Section 10 - Variance 
An Owner may submit a request for a variance from the requirements of these Guidelines with 
an ACC application.

and may amended from time to time as best suits this balance. The governing documents 
authorize the Association through the Board and the ACC to develop guidelines which 
supplement the declarant's original specifications in the governing documents. 

Section 3 - Organization of Topics 
Any modification or addition to construction can be specified almost entirely by its properties 
(color, size, material, texture, etc.). So, each major element of the exterior of a Unit is listed 
herein with the properties that may or may not be modified, and how so. Whenever possible, 
rationale for the decision is included. 

Section 4 - Definition of Impervious Cover 
Impervious Cover is defined in Chapter 25-8-1(11) of the Austin City Code as "the total area 
of any surface that prevents the infiltration of water into the ground, such as roads, parking 
areas, concrete, and buildings." Other items included in or excluded from Impervious Cover 
calculations are found in Chapter 25-8-63 of the Austin City Code, titled Impervious Cover 

Architectural Control Guidelines - Independence Park Condominium Community, Inc. Page2 



2021059562 Page 15 of 20 

Calculations. In general, anything that has horizontal surface area and that prevents rainwater 
from reaching the ground is considered impervious coverage. Common examples include (but 
are not limited to) decks, sheds, patios, concrete, etc. Each Unit is allotted 150 square feet of 
impervious cover in addition to the existing footprint of the Unit as of DA TE OF 
RECORDING. 

Section 5 - Responsibility 
It is the responsibility of the Owner to ensure the Guidelines are adhered to for his or her Unit 
and to ensure any exterior modification to the Unit is well-maintained. Owners must maintain 
records of impervious cover additions to their Units in terms of total square footage and not 
exceed the amount allocated to each Unit as provided herein. Owners must assist the ACC in

Section 1 - Purpose 
Pursuant to the Resolution of the Board of Directors of the Independence Park Condominium 
Community, Inc., recorded under Document No. 2012212132 of the Official Public Records 
of Travis County, Texas (the "Resolution") there was formed an Architectural Control 
Committee ("ACC") which is governed by a Charter found in the appendix to the Resolution. 
The ACC was established to set guidelines to help govern the appearance of the community 
and to facilitate compliance with the Declaration of Condominium Regime for Independence 
Park Condominiums (A Residential Condominium in Travis County, Texas), recorded under 
Document No. 2007059517 of the Official Public Records of Travis County, Texas as it has 
been or may be amended from time to time (the "Declaration") and other governing 
documents oflndependence Park Condominium Community, Inc. (the "Association"), which 
include but are not limited to the Independence Park Community Manual, recorded under

and other governing 
documents oflndependence Park Condominium Community, Inc. (the "Association"), which 
include but are not limited to the Independence Park Community Manual, recorded under 
Document No. 2007059518 of the Official Public Records of Travis County, Texas, the 
Independence Park Condominiums First Amendment to Rules and Regulations, recorded 
under Document No. 2007230444 of the Official Public Records of Travis County, Texas, the 
Independence Park Condominiums Second Amendment to Rules and Regulations, recorded 
under Document No. 2008165360 of the Official Public Records of Travis County, Texas, the 
Independence Park Condominiums Supplement to Community Manual, recorded under 
Document No. 2011149942 of the Official Public Records of Travis County, Texas, and the 
Independence Park Condominium Community, Inc. Policy regarding For Sale/For Lease 
Signs, recorded under Document No. 2014093214 of the Official Public Records of Travis 
County, Texas, as such instruments may be amended or supplemented from time to time. The 
purpose of these Architectural Control Guidelines (the "Guidelines") is to augment and clarify 
the stipulations set out in the governing documents of the Association, as they may be 
amended from time to time. 

Section 2 - Principles 
The Association must ever balance two factors. The first is the desire of Owners to be 
comfortable in their Units, express their creativity through the appearance of their Units, and 
take actions as needed to sustain and improve the relative value of their Units. The second is 
the need to ensure compliance with the governing documents of the Association and 
consistency throughout the Property. These Guidelines are designed with that purpose in mind 
and may amended from time to time as best suits this balance. The governing documents 
authorize the Association through the Board and the ACC to develop guidelines which

maintain 
records of impervious cover additions to their Units in terms of total square footage and not 
exceed the amount allocated to each Unit as provided herein. Owners must assist the ACC in 
accurate determination of impervious cover used in the community as a whole and submit to 
the ACC any Residential Permit for review prior to approval of any modifications. 

Section 6 - Modification without ACC Application 
To reduce unnecessary administration and allow for more Owner creativity, the Board and 
ACC, by approving these Guidelines, grants to the Owners the permission to complete the 
following types of exterior modifications without submission of an ACC application or fee. 

A. Installation of front entrance screen door 
• Commercial quality doors and installations are required 
• Style must complement the exterior Unit design 

B. Installation of rain gutters (without receptacle) 
• Commercial quality materials and installation are required 
• Color must complement the style of the Unit 

C. Fencing around plants or trees in the rear yard 
• Commercial quality fence materials are required 
• Height is limited to eighteen inches (18") without ACC approval 

D. Address Numerals 
• The size, shape, and style of residential address numerals affixed to a Unit 

does not require ACC approval 
• Residential address numerals on curb area will be maintained by the HOA. 

E. Garage Doors 
• May be replaced with doors of the same style used in original construction only 

(including windows) without ACC approval. 
• Must be painted primary color of the unit. 

F. House Exterior Color 
• Re-painting a Unit in the same color(s) is permitted without ACC 

approval. 

G. Common Area Fence 
• Material is restricted to four inch ( 4") wooden slats (pickets). Fence pickets

documents.content:
Introduction 
 
These guidelines are an effort to simplify acceptance of your proposed 
improvements on, and use of your property in Green Haven Ranch.  Following these 
guidelines does not guarantee approval by the Architectural Committee (ARC) but 
gives you the greatest chance of approval without undue work and additional 
requests for information. 
 
 

Signs 
 
The following signs are generally acceptable as long as they don’t exceed 6 square 
feet in area: 
 

 Builder Signs 
 For Sale Signs 
 Academic Signs 
 Political Signs 

 
 

Outbuildings – Permanent & Portable 
 
Outbuildings under 121 square feet, less than 7 feet tall and behind a privacy 
fence and/or generally out of public view can be made of any material.  
 
 
Between 121 and 700 square feet and NOT considered living quarters 
 

 Roofing material of either shingles or metal 

 Exterior walls constructed of brick, stone, stucco, cement board, wood siding 
or vinyl siding 

 Coloring that is consistent with main structure 

 Is situated on the property in such a manner so as not to detract from the 
residential character of the property 

 
NOTE: If the same roofing materials as the main structure are used, then the roofing 
should match the main structure 
 
 
Greater than 700 square feet or considered additional living quarters 
 

 Must be on a slab foundation 
 Must be 75% masonry and be consistent with main structure 

 Roofing material must match main structure 



 Color must be consistent with main structure 

 Is situated on the property in such a manner so as not to detract from the 
residential character of the property 
 

 
NOTE: If there are multiple outbuildings greater than 120 square feet, it is 
recommended that the buildings be consistent with one another. 
 
 

Landscaping 
 
Care should be exercised in the landscaping and in planting and maintenance of 
trees and shrubs on the property to prevent drainage problems or obstruction of

documents.content:
Plant & Tree Beds 
• May be fenced, lined with stone, plant material, or bed edging with ACC 

approval 

Architectural Control Guidelines - Independence Park Condominium Community, Inc. Page4 



2021059562 Page 17 of 20 

F. Front Door 
• Color may be changed with ACC approval 

G. Front Porch Fence, Gate & Screen allowed, with ACC approval 
• An iron fence, and/or fence made of metal material that is either powder- coated 

or anodized is allowed, with ACC approval. In all cases the railings dimensions 
shall be one inch (l ") x one inch (l ") or less 

• A gate of the same material and height as the fence is allowed, with ACC 
approval 

• A gate latch which can be opened from either side is allowed, with ACC 
approval 

• In all cases, fence and/or gate height may not exceed 42" above the front 
patio deck 

• Painted metal or vinyl-covered metal is not allowed as a fence or gate 
material 

• Front porches may not be screened 

H. Rear Patio Screening 
• Rear patios may be enclosed by a screen enclosure, with ACC approval 
• Plans for an enclosure must include an exit door that opens to the outside. 

I. Garage Door 

• Any replacement garage door that differs in design from the one installed with 
original construction requires ACC approval 

• Reason: the garage door style is part of the general design of the community 

J. Common Area Yard Fence 

• Fences may be painted or colored differently on sides not visible from the 
street, with ACCapproval 

• Fence height is restricted to six feet (6') maximum, except where the 
developer has previously permitted a variance for a different height or 
additional lattice-work. Changing a fence structure is with ACC approval, 
only. 

K. Property Perimeter Fence 

• Any alteration from original design or color requires ACC approval 

• Reason: often these fences abut city and the greater community, and a 
pleasant and consistent image is desired to be projected 

L. Waste/Recycle Bin Fences or Facades
